South Sudan Joint Response 7 (SSJR7)

description.narrative:
In Malakal Town and Malakal PoC, 13.715 vulnerable people will benefit from FSL, MPC and Protection support provided by Plan. JR locations have seen an increasing number of returnees from refugee and IDP camps and flood affected areas, which have created stress on existing humanitarian services. Congested settlement, coupled with COVID-19 restrictions and food insecurity, has resulted in increasing protection concerns as adolescents and families tend to adapt negative coping mechanisms. Therefore, Plan will increase the Protection support provided in 2021. Plan will continue to use the innovative Up2U card to distribute cash to beneficiaries in 2021, and more CFW activities have been planned for, seeing their success in 2020, and also taking into consideration the need for more roads leading to schools and socio-economic centres (market/churches) will need to be cleared to facilitate everyday life, especially as more displaced people return to Malakal. Considering the impact of school and CFS closure on GBV and CP activities in 2020, in 2021 small group-based approaches will be used to reach adolescent girls and children.
Activities per sector: Plan will provide training/coaching on agro-practices, agricultural inputs (crops and vegetable seeds) and cash to protect livelihood assets to 500 vulnerable HH. Regular price monitoring will be done to ensure CVA programming is and remain possible; conditional cash will be provided in the form of e-vouchers using the Up2U system for 4 months. 4 events will be organised to raise awareness on SRHR, GBV and MHM and 2 Intergenerational dialogues to discuss CEFM and SRHR. 12 Adolescent clubs (AC) and 4 Youth Clubs (YC) members ( 300 individuals) will be trained and coached on basic GBV, SRHR, gender equality, dialoguing and awareness raising methods as well as on their roles and responsibilities and they will be engaged in GBV safety audits and Risk and Resources Mapping. 50 Adolescent mothers will be trained on positive parenting, basics of GBV, MHM and SRHR. 150 teachers and other educational personal, 80 traditional and religious leaders and 80 staff from service providers and line ministries will be trained on adolescent development, including SRHR, gender equality and GBV, incl. referral pathways. 310 adolescent girls at risk of GBV will be sensitized on GBV and MHM and provided with dignity kits to protect them from GBV, along with 5 matrons in school. Support will be provided to Youth Unions to perform group activities for child and youth well-being, especially sports. 150 most vulnerable HHs (900 indiv.) unable to participate in the CFW, nor farming, will be provided with unconditional multipurpose cash. Unconditional cash will be provided in the form of physical cash for 4 months. 300 vulnerable HH (1800 indiv.) will be provided with conditional multipurpose cash in the frame of a Cash for Work program to contribute to the rehabilitation of community assets.

Plan will continue to strengthen the capacities of their local partners as part of the ongoing project through training and on the job support. Localization efforts in 2021 will include additional activities to ensure that as a SSJR, we contribute to ensuring we amplify local voices. Joint coordination budget will be used to improve visibility of local partners and make it a priority to improve it nationally and internationally, and budget has also been reserved to ensure our partners are able to participate in regional and/or global meetings and discussions related to localization, and to ensure that they are able to share experiences and learning at these engagements.

Prior to the emergence of the COVID-19 threat, more than half of South Sudan’s population, 6.5 million people out of nearly 12 million, were expected to face severe food insecurity (IPC Phase 3 and above) at the height of the annual hunger season (May-July 2020) . Malakal is at IPC 4 level (sever food insecurity), mainly inhabited by IDPs and returnees. There is significant increase in teenage pregnancy and abortion. Child marriage, sexual violence, self-harm and psychological distress in Malakal continues to increase, heavy rain and subsequent floods forced many people to move to Malakal from the surrounding flood affected counties. Malakal has unmet FSL, MPC and protection needs as FSL partners faced funding shortage and WFP also reduced the quantity of food ration per HH. Increasing returnees to Malakal created stress on existing humanitarian services (protection, FSL and MPC). Congested settlement coupled with COVID 19 restrictions and food insecurity has resulted in increasing protection concerns such as early/forced marriage, teenage pregnancy, abortion, self-harm/psychological harm and child labor as adolescents and families tend to adapt negative coping mechanisms.

SUMMARY: The SSJR Alliance with Save the Children (lead), Plan Nederland, War Child Holland, Tearfund, CARE, Stichting Red een Kind, Dorcas Aid International implements from 1.1 - 31.12.2021 in Pibor, Koch, Malakal and Fashoda, Aweil East, and Wau and Jur River. Plan Nederland will implement its project in Malakal, continues to respond to increasing protection concerns, and will help to reach more vulnerable HHs with FSL supports and MPC assistance to address severe food insecurity reported. Plan will reach 13.715 vulnerable people.

The SSJR program will continue to provide life-saving assistance and aim to enhance the transition from humanitarian assistance to resilience programming, addressing root causes, enabling vulnerable and at-risk communities to build resilience to acute shocks and chronic stresses, and recover from crisis. Lastly, the SSJR program will continue to address critical problems relating to physical and mental wellbeing, strongly reinforcing protection throughout the program, both integrated within other sectors, and as a separate sector. The Alliance will continue to all 2020 HRP strategic objectives and will support efforts in containing and preventing the spread of COVID-19 while employing a COVID-19 adapted approach to respond to the ongoing emergency.
Plan continues to respond to an increasing protection concerns and will scale up GBV, CP, PSS and case management interventions to support additional children affected by sexual health and protection concerns in Malakal. It will help to reach more vulnerable HHs with FSL supports and MPC assistance to address sever food insecurity reported in Malakal.
The SSJR7 is a continuation of the South Sudan program funded by the Dutch Relief Alliance.

The target group for the SSJR 2021 will continue to target the most vulnerable households amongst IDPS, returnees and host communities, with a particular focus on child-headed households, female headed households, PLW, elderly, households with children facing SAM/MAM, malnourished children, youth, vulnerable adolescent boys and girls.

title.narrative: WASH SDG Uganda (including COVID-19 prevention)

description.narrative: Activities of Plan International Uganda will contribute to, and enhance the national WASH strategy of the Government of Uganda. Based on discussions with the national level government and previous working experience in Uganda, Plan International Uganda will work in Kamuli, Buyende and Nebbi. These districts are all lacking behind in terms of access to WASH, but also in terms of poverty. Based on national data and baseline data collected in the intervention areas, it became apparent that the number of people that lack access to water, sanitation and hygiene services in Uganda is still very high. There is still a lot to be done in order to achieve the country SDG targets. This is the case for all three sub-sectors, but sanitation and hygiene are lagging behind even more than water and are receiving less government budget and priority. For this reason, the WASH SDG Consortium has chosen for an integrated WASH approach, but with a strong emphasis on sanitation and hygiene. The project is aligned and builds onto the achievements of the ongoing “A deadly serious matter: Menstrual Hygiene Management in Uganda” Under this project Plan reaches out to over 150,000 adolescent girls and young women with an opportunity to take a full part in education and work, without menstruation being a limiting factor. It build Knowledge about personal hygiene and menstrual cycles among girls, boys, parents, teachers and communities, accompanied by a change in behaviour with regard to personal hygiene during menstruation, partly due to the availability of affordable sanitary protection.

Financial sustainability: In a bid to build a sense of ownership, communities will be required to contribute a cash contribution (€ 51) of per water source in line with the critical minimum requirements under the WASH sector. An appropriate tariff (between € 0.74 per household per year) will be negotiated and agreed upon to ensure effective operation and maintenance of water sources Institutional sustainability: School and community level structures to support community based maintenance systems will be developed, trained and mentored over the project phase to enhance their autonomous functioning beyond the life of the project. On the other hand, the project’s actors will transfer the installed materials to the officials who are in charge of the water resources through official transfer ceremonies.
Ecological sustainability: The project will utilise a technology for water extraction in selected schools that does not impact on the environment in the selected schools. The selected areas have a large amount of water, so the withdrawal is not a problem for the environment and the future water supply. In addition, excess water will be used for irrigation of fruit trees in school that have a positive contribution to environment. Improvements in sanitation and hygiene practices will also have a positive impact on the environment as it will reduce contamination of the groundwater.
Technical sustainability: The chosen technology (drilling of deep boreholes), is a relative simple technique. The technical level required for its repair and maintenance is simple, although the lack of capabilities makes it necessary to provide training for the local technicians. As part of advocacy efforts, Plan will engage with the district local governments of Nebbi, Kamuli and Buyende to establish a functional faecal sludge management system and encourage schools to mobilize resources for emptying, transporting and disposing off the wastes.
Social sustainability: The 22 water management committees will manage the operation and maintenance of boreholes hand pumps. Their members are democratically selected by their communities, also considering the female and child representation (at least one boy and one girl and 50% women representation). This will grant that the diversity of opinion will be considered in all the decisions that the committees will take. The school Health Clubs established in schools will promote the participation of the youngest people and enhancing their social inclusion in the local policies.

Pathway 1: The vision of the sub-programme for this pathway is that by the end of the programme, at least 150 communities in the target areas reach the ODF status and have moved up the sanitation and hygiene ladder. Women, girls and other socially excluded groups are empowered, resulting in an increased level of participation of women/girls and other excluded groups in WASH activities in the community, shared WASH workload and decision making in the household and an increased level of leadership positions in communities around WASH. Fathers and mothers have also improved their knowledge and practices about baby WASH. In order to make progress towards this, Plan will enhance the capacity of the responsible government structures on gender and social inclusive community demand-driven approaches which aims to eliminate open defecation. Capacity will be built on how to improve knowledge attitudes and practices (KAP) for handwashing, MHM and baby WASH. In addition, Plan will support the government in the implementation of behaviour change activities and help them to enhance their monitoring capacity to ensure monitoring and follow up. Other CSOs will be trained so they can support other districts with other donor funding, to enhance their capacity on inclusive behaviour change interventions which include baby WASH messages. Finally, Plan will use the champion of change approach and the GWMT to improve and monitor levels of participation of women and socially excluded groups throughout the programme. For further information on these can be found in the inception report (July 2018). Through these tools, men and boys will also be targeted to ensure women and girls are given the space within WASH activities and decision making and the (baby) WASH workload is shared more equally.
Pathway 2: The vision of the sub-programme for this pathway is that by the end of the programme the target communities and schools have access to affordable and sustainable menstrual hygienic products, liquid soap and climate resilient latrine options. In order to make progress towards this vision, Plan will support the development of locally made liquid soap and climate resilient latrine options together with community groups (like village health workers) and local entrepreneurs. Plan will train teachers and school pupils (girls and boys) on how to make reusable sanitary pads. Members of village saving and loan associations (VSLA) and already established small-scale entrepreneurs, especially women, will also receive marketing and financial business skill training to stimulate the beginning of selling reusable sanitary pads, liquid soap and climate resilient latrine options. To increase access to credit for WASH businesses, Plan will promote and/or strengthen the VSLAs in 60 rural communities and link those to the established financial institutions. In order to improve sanitation and water service provision at schools, Plan, together with the school management, will construct latrines for boys and girls. These latrines will include a toilet for people with disabilities and MHM facilities. Water points will also be rehabilitated or constructed at 22 schools. All facilities will only be constructed after the school management has developed a financially sustainable operation and maintenance plan.
Pathway 3: The vision of the sub-programme for this pathway is that by the end of the programme, the national CLTS manual is revised and is gender and social inclusive and standardised school latrine designs in the national school WASH guidelines include an MHM component. At the district level gender transformation and social inclusion is mainstreamed in all WASH programmes and sufficient budget is allocated to implement these programmes. The capacity of the district health and community workers has been enhanced and they are now implementing gender transformative and inclusive CLTS. Women and girls and other socially excluded groups will amplify their voices/demand for their WASH rights including active participation in community WASH leadership and decision making. As a consequence at least 50% of the WASH governance committees are represented by women and socially excluded groups and whose voices are heard. District local government also has a harmonised understanding of and effectively reports on the SDG 6 indicators, target 6.1 and 6.2. In order to make progress towards this, Plan, as the chair of the national CLTS taskforce, will work with the Ministry of Health to revise the national CLTS manual to be gender and socially inclusive and to ensure that standardised school latrine designs include MHM facilities. Plan will strengthen the WASH planning and coordination at district and national level and work with the technical support unit of the Ministry of Water and Environment (MWE) to facilitate district local governments to review and to add resources to the district based WASH investment plans. Similarly, Plan shall invest time/budget to rev

SUMMARY: The WASH SDG Project in Uganda is part of the Netherlands WASH SDG Consortium Programme which is implemented by WASH Alliance International (WAI), SNV and Plan International in Uganda, Ethiopia, Zambia, Tanzania, Indonesia, Bangladesh and Nepal. Plan International Uganda implements the WASH SDG programme in nine sub counties in the districts of Kamuli, Buyende and Nebbi in Uganda. Water and sanitation coverage in Uganda has not reached the national and global MDG targets. The programme will increase access to sanitation for 193,000 people and hygiene for 90,200 people. The programme will also improve access to water, sanitation and hygiene in at least 9 schools in the selected Districts. The programme does not only focus on improving access to water, sanitation and hygiene but also on improving the position of women, girls and other socially excluded groups.

The WASH SDG programme-level Theory of Change (ToC) was developed and validated in early 2017. As established in the proposal approved by DGIS, the WASH SDG programme is built on the assumption that sustainable and equitable use of WASH by all can be achieved in a locality through: • Improved behaviour change interventions that lead to increased demand for improved WASH facilities and practices • Improved WASH service provision that leads to increased availability and affordability of WASH products and services • Strengthened WASH governance and institutional framework that leads to governments enabling efficient and effective delivery of inclusive and sustainable WASH services. In order for WASH to be sustainable and equitable, the programme also assumes that two additional approaches should be endorsed and integrated transversally: • gender transformative and socially inclusive WASH • climate resilient WASH services.

The programme will increase access to sanitation for 193,000 people and hygiene for 90,200 people in the selected villages in Kamuli, Buyende and Nebbi. And the programme will improve access to water, sanitation and hygiene in at least 9 schools in the selected Districts. The selected villages were chosen because access to WASH is limited and a high percentage of the households living in these villages have a low income status.

Water and sanitation coverage in Uganda has not reached the national and global MDG targets. In the target areas access to basic water is 30,2%. Access to basic sanitation facilities is even lower at 24% and 92% of the target population does not have access to any handwashing facilities. Uganda is ranked 64 out of the 144 countries in the global gender index. Gender gaps and inequalities (employment and control of resources), discrimination, exclusion and marginalisation continue to remain despite increased levels of girls and women empowerment. The nature of the rural society in the selected districts continues to overload girls and women with WASH activities at household level including water collection and household and latrine management. In comparison to boys and men, women spend long hours per day on household activities. The gender household division of labour is biased against women which leaves them with limited time to meaningfully participate in WASH decision-making spaces at community level. Boys and men continue to dominate and take leadership roles in WASH management committees and are highly influential in decision making on WASH issues, leaving women with little or no influence. Women are often traditional members on the committees with no control and power. Additionally, women habitually lack self-esteem to speak up because culturally it is perceived they should be submissive and not challenge male views.

WASH First: Scaling up WASH SDG efforts: the first line of defence against COVID-19 - Uganda

description.narrative: In Uganda the first case of COVID-19 was confirmed on the 22nd of March 2020 and , first COVID-19 death was reported on the 24th of July 2020. Although confirmed cases initially were low in Uganda partly due to limiting testing, they increased substantially in the second halve of 2020. On the 18th of March 2020 lock down measures were taken in Uganda that included the closure of borders, schools, public places, businesses and transport. Plan International Uganda will work in Nebbi District, bordering Congo. The effects of the lockdown there include lack of safe water points, famine, loss of jobs and an increase in domestic violence. Communities have reported an increase in water usage, which is has resulted in long queues for water and long distances to travel for water and limited access to menstrual hygiene products due to the disruption of the supply chain.

Institutional: By involving local government and local stakeholders, the ownership of the Programme will be anchored in the local institutional structure.
Social: The active participation of the target groups is essential to ensure that we respond to their specific needs. The overall goal of this program is the “promotion of health-related hygiene practices to prevent further spread of COVID-19 through awareness raising and improved access to WASH services.” The intervention will ensure that the achievement of the SDG 6 goals does not come to a standstill in the intervention areas.

Plan International Uganda has been working in Uganda since 1992 and since Nebbi since 2018. This project will build on and be aligned with the existing WASH SDG project that is already being implemented in the target district Nebbi and will leverage on the human resource already in place to implement the proposed activities.

Plan International Uganda will implement the following activities on the 6 intervention strategies:
Intervention strategy 1: Awareness raising (campaigns and mass media campaigns) on COVID-19 • Implement gender and socially inclusive hygiene promotion campaigns in public places and communities using vehicle caravans. Translate existing handwashing IEC materials including gender/ social inclusive and child friendly versions. • Procure airtime on electronic media to relay campaign gender sensitive and inclusive messages to create awareness on prevention and risk mitigation around public settings, water points and markets. • Localise and print gender sensitive information, education and communication materials on COVID-19 and hand hygiene.
Intervention strategy 2: Direct information sharing and messaging • Adopt non-conventional approaches including remote meetings to enable sub-county and community engagements. • Support training of health workers, village health teams (VHTs) and surveillance officers on prevention measures for COVID 19, using CMEs and on-the-job training. • Support training for VHTs and water and sanitation committees in making soap, sanitary pads and face masks. This training will enable VHTs and WASH committees to expand access to necessary WASH commodities.
Intervention strategy 3: Improving access to safe drinking water and water supply for handwashing, as well as menstrual health and sanitation (including safe disposal of waste) • Support the district to restore water supply through rehabilitation of boreholes in public places, health centres and communities. This will facilitate effective hand hygiene and access to safe water.
Intervention strategy 4: Improving access to safe handwashing facilities • Procure and distribute hands-free handwashing facilities and detergents in public places including health care centres and water points. Care will be taken to ensure that such facilities are accessible to the vulnerable target groups both in terms of placement and operation.
Intervention strategy 5: Access to hygiene products including soap, disinfectant, PPE and menstrual hygiene products • Procure items to support VHTs and health educators to increase access to hygiene products for target groups. These include: mega-phones (for targeted information provision), education and communication materials, handwashing stations, soap, detergent and facial masks. • Procurement and distribution of hygiene kits for girls and women.
Intervention strategy 6: COVID-related coordination meetings with local government and other stakeholders • Strengthen coordination of COVID-19 initiatives at the district and regional levels by revamping the district water and sanitation coordination committees and through UWASNET. • Support advocacy and influencing efforts at the national level by documenting and publicizing the impact of COVID-19 on the WASH sector.

SUMMARY The WASH First Programme aims to combat the spread of COVID-19 through improving access to water, sanitation and hygiene. The programme is funded by the Ministry of Foreign Affairs and implemented by the WASH SDG Consortium partners SNV, WASH Alliance International and Plan International Netherlands. Plan is implementing the programme in 4 countries: Indonesia, Uganda, Kenya and Mozambique. The programme started in September 2020 and will run until the end of November 2022.In Uganda, Plan International is implementing the programme in Nebbi District. Together with the District Plan International Uganda will: (1) Raise awareness of the people living in the target areas on how to prevent the spread of COVID-19, (2) Provide the people living in the target areas with hygiene kits, disinfected equipment, soap and personal protective equipment to enable them to practice good hygiene, (3) Improve access to water facilities by rehabilitating water points.

The WASH First programme focuses on specific objectives targeting high at-risk and most marginalized populations for which a full results framework has been elaborated. Main results in order to reduce the spread of the virus: • Result 1: Enhanced understanding of individuals, communities, health workers, schools and WASH service providers about mitigation measures against COVID-19 transmission • Result 2: Population at risk of COVID-19 have sufficient and constant access to commodities and consumables (handwashing facilities, disinfection equipment, soap, hygiene kits including menstrual health products and personal protective equipment (PPE)) • Result 3: Population at risk of COVID-19 have safe (considering safeguarding and security) access to water and sanitation services through the construction of new and repair of non-functional water and sanitation facilities or through temporary/mobile supplies/services.

The end beneficiaries of the programme activities will the vulnerable and at risk groups living in the 4 low income rural sub counties Kucwiny, Nyaravur, Akworo and Parombo in Nebbi District that boarders Congo.

title.narrative: Vietnam Acute Joint Response - Joint Budget

description.narrative: SUMMARY The DRA Acute Response concerning the flooding and typhoon in Viet Nam will be implemented through an alliance led by Plan International, consisting of World Vision, Oxfam and CARE, in addition to local implementing partners in Viet Nam. Plan International is the lead of this VNMJR. The Joint Budget serves for the coordination of Plan International as Joint Response Lead to: 1) Hire a field coordinator to be based in Viet Nam in order to coordinate and monitor implementation on the ground and facilitate collaboration, localization and accountability, as well as support staff including Finance and M&E; 2) Organize at least a kick-off meeting, a mid-term meeting, and a Rapid Realtime Review; 3) Support the external evaluation and Meta audit. The Joint budget is managed by Plan International but subject to agreements within the alliance. The coordinator facilitates regular communication on utilization of the Joint Budget, which can be further defined during the kick-off workshop in-country.

Since 6 October 2020, the Central region of Viet Nam has been experiencing prolonged heavy rainfall as a result of a combination of numerous weather systems; Tropical Storm LINFA, Tropical Storm NANGKA, and the Inter Tropical Convergence Zone combined with cold air.
Besides the existing flooding and ongoing rainfall, Typhoon Molave hit Viet Nam in the morning of October 28th. Molave made landfall between Quang Ngai and Quang Nam provinces (central Viet Nam) as a typhoon before dissipating on 29 October. According to UNOCHA, landslides triggered by heavy rain in Quang Nam Province resulted in at least 68 fatalities. In total, due to the typhoon and the flooding, more than 374.631 people have been evacuated. Millions were left without electricity and an additional 56,000 houses damaged.
According to the UN FRP an estimated 7.7 million people live in areas affected by flooding caused by the multiple storms and typhoon, with some 1.5 million people in nine provinces directly affected. Of those people directly affected by the current disaster, some 753,000 are women and girls, 134,000 are children under five, and 143,000 are over 65 years old. A rapid needs assessment conducted by UNICEF, identified 1,5 million children at risk.

The JR proposes a multi-sectoral response to the typhoon and flooding, taking into account immediate relief as well as early recovery in a phased approach, in line with the UN Floods Response Plan which puts forward this phased approach (see UN Sector Analysis). The JR will be implemented in the four provinces among the most affected by the flooding and typhoon Molave, including Quang Binh, Quang Tri, Ha Tinh and Quang Nam.
The VNMJR commits itself to 2 of the 4 objectives set out in the Viet Nam Flood HRP: 1. Deliver immediate, lifesaving assistance to those with the most urgent needs, in support of the Government response and in line with Government requests for assistance. 2. Ensure access to multi sectoral assistance and reestablish critical services. Promote the repair of key public service infrastructure in affected provinces, ensure food security, by restoring lost food stock, livestock and livelihoods, ensure access to sustainable drinking water, sanitation facilities and hygiene supplies, housing, replacement of productive assets and household items, and access to basic medical, social and public services to support the affected population transition to recovery and rebuild their lives and livelihoods.

The JR will be implemented by four DRA members, Plan International, CARE, Oxfam Novib and World Vision, in coordination and partnership with local partners in Viet Nam. All four members have an existing humanitarian portfolio in Viet Nam and have been responding to the flooding since the beginning of October. Partners have engaged in a Rapid Needs Assessment jointly in the second half of October, which has informed the JR. All partners have offices and/or local partner offices in the response areas and humanitarian staff in-country, including fully operational Emergency Response Teams. Partners have been responding to the typhoon, mainly during the immediate response phase through the distribution of NFIs, including hygiene kits and household items. All partners have a solid track-record of the sectors, particularly FSL, WASH and Protection, both in humanitarian and development contexts. In-country, partners engage in the Working Groups and UN coordination mechanisms to ensure programming is well-coordinated and in line with sector-wide standards.

The response uses a multi-sector approach with holistic Shelter/NFIs, WASH, Food Security and Livelihoods (FSL), Multi-Purpose Cash Assistance (MPCA) and Protection programs. Core activities are:
Food Security & Livelihoods (FSL): The JR works to ensure people are able to meet their basic food needs (FSC-I2) and are provided with resources to protect and start rebuilding their livelihoods (FSC-I1). This includes the following activities: - Provision of food baskets to the families with vulnerable children and other poor, vulnerable groups such as the elderly, People with Disability (PwD), lactating women; female-headed families. Noting that immediate food needs are met by other partners and the government of Viet Nam, this will be a small component and this JR mainly focuses on medium-term FSL support and cash grants, as described below. - Execution of a livelihoods/market assessment to determine the agricultural needs and the feasibility of cash grants. - Provision of technical training to support livelihood recovery activities. - Provision of conditional cash grants for agricultural support and production inputs for small-holders farms and households to support short crops recovery.
Shelter/Non-Food Items (NFI): The JR focuses on individual household shelters and non-food items to ensure people in the direct aftermath of the floods have access to dignified and safe shelter solutions (SHL-I1) and NFIs (SHL-I4), including: - Provision of household kits in response to the destruction of assets in the households, taking into account winterization, ensuring particularly children have warm clothing for when temperatures decrease to less than 15 degrees. - Provision of constructions materials for repair for vulnerable families whose houses have been damaged.
Water, Sanitation and Hygiene (WASH): The JR WASH response focuses onensuring access to safe and sufficient water (WSH-I4), hygiene promotion and provision of soaps (WSH-I1) and hygiene promotion (WSH-I6) through reaching people with awareness programming. This includes the following activities: - Improving access to clean water through water testing, distribution of household-led water treatment solutions and provision of water containers and water taps to people and communities without access to clean water. - Reparation and installment of damaged small-scale water supply facilities. - Distribution of gender-sensitive hygiene kits, including soap and cleaning materials and taking into account Menstrual Hygiene Management (MHM), particularly for girls and women in evacuation centers. - Organization of information campaigns to promote hygiene measures, also taking into account the risks of COVID-19.
Multi-purpose cash (MPC): The JR provides both unconditional (CSH-I1) and conditional (CSH-I2) unrestricted cash assistance to beneficiaries based on their situations and identified needs: - Distribution of unconditional multi-purpose cash grants in line with Viet Nam’s CWG’s Minimum Expenditure Basket guidance, as the markets are mostly functioning, and people have suffered significant loss of livelihoods due to the floods and exacerbated by the COVID-19 lockdown. - Provision of conditional cash grants/Cash for Work (C4W) opportunities to selected households. Partners will work with affected populations to identify livelihood opportunities, including basic repair and public work in the early recovery phase.
Protection: The JR mainstreams protection throughout the response is in line with HRP objectives, and also ensures specific programming to ensure people receive an appropriate response to protection risks (PRO-I2), are provided with information (PRO-I5) and children receive support specific to their needs (PRO-I15). This includes: - Organization of psychosocial support (PSS) groups and other group activities for affected children in Child-Friendly Spaces inside primary schools. - Awareness-raising and training on Protection issues.

The target group for the response includes those affected by flooding and heavy rainfall. Priority is given to vulnerable families with pre-existing vulnerabilities before the disaster, taking into account the Minimum Expenditure Basket, and who have suffered human loss, loss of house, assets or livelihoods.

participating-org.narrative: Ministry of Foreign Affairs of the Netherlands

policy-marker.narrative: Protection and Assistance in Emergencies (Disaster Risk Management)

title.narrative: Vietnam Acute Joint Response (Programme)

description.narrative: SUMMARY 7.7 million people in Vietnam were affected by the typhoon and tropical storms in Vietnam in October 2020. This project is a collaboration between the Dutch Relief Alliance partners to ensure the deliverance of immediate, lifesaving assistance to people in need, as well as focusing on early recovery and rehabilitation and re-establishing critical services. The Joint Response will ensure access to shelter solutions in the direct aftermath of the flooding, food security by restoring lost food stock, livestock and agricultural lands and the provision of cash assistance, as well as ensure access to drinking water, hygiene supplies and access to basic public services. Protection of women and children is mainstreamed throughout the response. A total of 116.324 people in the four provinces among the most affected by the flooding and typhoon Molave, including Quang Binh, Quang Tri, Ha Tinh and Quang Nam will benefit from lifesaving goods and services.

Since 6 October 2020, the Central region of Viet Nam has been experiencing prolonged heavy rainfall as a result of a combination of numerous weather systems; Tropical Storm LINFA, Tropical Storm NANGKA, and the Inter Tropical Convergence Zone combined with cold air.
Besides the existing flooding and ongoing rainfall, Typhoon Molave hit Viet Nam in the morning of October 28th. Molave made landfall between Quang Ngai and Quang Nam provinces (central Viet Nam) as a typhoon before dissipating on 29 October. According to UNOCHA, landslides triggered by heavy rain in Quang Nam Province resulted in at least 68 fatalities. In total, due to the typhoon and the flooding, more than 374.631 people have been evacuated. Millions were left without electricity and an additional 56,000 houses damaged.
According to the UN FRP an estimated 7.7 million people live in areas affected by flooding caused by the multiple storms and typhoon, with some 1.5 million people in nine provinces directly affected. Of those people directly affected by the current disaster, some 753,000 are women and girls, 134,000 are children under five, and 143,000 are over 65 years old. A rapid needs assessment conducted by UNICEF, identified 1,5 million children at risk.

The JR proposes a multi-sectoral response to the typhoon and flooding, taking into account immediate relief as well as early recovery in a phased approach, in line with the UN Floods Response Plan which puts forward this phased approach (see UN Sector Analysis). The JR will be implemented in the four provinces among the most affected by the flooding and typhoon Molave, including Quang Binh, Quang Tri, Ha Tinh and Quang Nam.
The VNMJR commits itself to 2 of the 4 objectives set out in the Viet Nam Flood HRP: 1. Deliver immediate, lifesaving assistance to those with the most urgent needs, in support of the Government response and in line with Government requests for assistance. 2. Ensure access to multi sectoral assistance and reestablish critical services. Promote the repair of key public service infrastructure in affected provinces, ensure food security, by restoring lost food stock, livestock and livelihoods, ensure access to sustainable drinking water, sanitation facilities and hygiene supplies, housing, replacement of productive assets and household items, and access to basic medical, social and public services to support the affected population transition to recovery and rebuild their lives and livelihoods.

The JR will be implemented by four DRA-members, Plan International, CARE, Oxfam Novib and World Vision, in coordination and partnership with local partners in Viet Nam. All four members have an existing humanitarian portfolio in Viet Nam and have been responding to the flooding since the beginning of October. Partners have engaged in a Rapid Needs Assessment jointly in the second half of October, which has informed the JR. All partners have offices and/or local partner offices in the response areas and humanitarian staff in-country, including fully operational Emergency Response Teams. Partners have been responding to the typhoon, mainly in the immediate response phase through the distribution of NFIs, including hygiene kits and household items. All partners have a solid track-record in the sectors, particularly FSL, WASH and Protection, both in humanitarian and development contexts. In-country, partners engage in the Working Groups and UN coordination mechanisms to ensure programming is well-coordinated and in line with sector-wide standards.

The response uses a multi-sector approach with holistic Shelter/NFIs, WASH, Food Security and Livelihoods (FSL), Multi-Purpose Cash Assistance (MPCA) and Protection programs. Core activities are:
Food Security & Livelihoods (FSL): The JR works to ensure people are able to meet their basic food needs (FSC-I2) and are provided with resources to protect and start rebuilding their livelihoods (FSC-I1). This includes the following activities: - Provision of food baskets to the families with vulnerable children and other poor, vulnerable groups such as the elderly, People with Disability (PwD), lactating women; female-headed families. Noting that immediate food needs are met by other partners and the government of Viet Nam, this will be a small component and this JR mainly focuses on medium-term FSL support and cash grants, as described below. - Execution of a livelihoods/market assessment to determine the agricultural needs and the feasibility of cash grants. - Provision of technical training to support livelihood recovery activities. - Provision of conditional cash grants for agricultural support and production inputs for small-holders farms and households to support short crops recovery.
Shelter/Non-Food Items (NFI): The JR focuses on individual household shelters and non-food items to ensure people in the direct aftermath of the floods have access to dignified and safe shelter solutions (SHL-I1) and NFIs (SHL-I4), including: - Provision of household kits in response to the destruction of assets in the households, taking into account winterization, ensuring particularly children have warm clothing for when temperatures decrease to less than 15 degrees. - Provision of constructions materials for repair for vulnerable families whose houses have been damaged.
Water, Sanitation and Hygiene (WASH): The JR WASH response focuses around ensuring access to safe and sufficient water (WSH-I4), hygiene promotion and provision of soaps (WSH-I1) and hygiene promotion (WSH-I6) through reaching people with awareness programming. This includes the following activities: - Improving access to clean water through water testing, distribution of household-led water treatment solutions and provision of water containers and water taps to people and communities without access to clean water. - Reparation and installment of damaged small-scale water supply facilities. - Distribution of gender-sensitive hygiene kits, including soap and cleaning materials and taking into account Menstrual Hygiene Management (MHM), particularly for girls and women in evacuation centers. - Organization of information campaigns to promote hygiene measures, also taking into account the risks of COVID-19.
Multi-purpose cash (MPC): The JR provides both unconditional (CSH-I1) and conditional (CSH-I2) unrestricted cash assistance to beneficiaries based on their situations and identified needs: - Distribution of unconditional multi-purpose cash grants in line with Viet Nam’s CWG’s Minimum Expenditure Basket guidance, as the markets are mostly functioning, and people have suffered significant loss of livelihoods due to the floods and exacerbated by the COVID-19 lockdown. - Provision of conditional cash grants/Cash for Work (C4W) opportunities to selected households. Partners will work with affected populations to identify livelihood opportunities, including basic repair and public work in the early recovery phase.
Protection: The JR mainstreams protection throughout the response is in line with HRP objectives, and also ensures specific programming to ensure people receive an appropriate response to protection risks (PRO-I2), are provided with information (PRO-I5) and children receive support specific to their needs (PRO-I15). This includes: - Organization of psychosocial support (PSS) groups and other group activities for affected children in Child-Friendly Spaces inside primary schools. - Awareness-raising and training on Protection issues.

The target group for the response includes those affected by flooding and heavy rainfall. Priority is given to vulnerable families with pre-existing vulnerabilities before the disaster, taking into account the Minimum Expenditure Basket, and who have suffered human loss, loss of house, assets or livelihoods.

participating-org.narrative: Ministry of Foreign Affairs of the Netherlands

title.narrative: WASH First: Scaling up WASH SDG efforts: the first line of defence against COVID-19

description.narrative: As from March 2020 COVID-19 quickly spread and was declared a pandemic. To date, official reports indicate a total of almost 15 million cases worldwide and over 600,000 deaths with many countries underreporting. Until there is a vaccine or treatment for COVID-19, there is no better cure than prevention. This pandemic clearly emphasized how deficient hygiene practices and the existing lack of prioritization of resilient, accessible and affordable water and sanitation systems affects everyone and puts global public health at risk. The crisis is further revealing inequities in WASH, between those with and without access to services, and between those with better and worse levels of service. Those without or with low quality services are less able to implement basic mitigation measures such as frequent handwashing with soap, social distancing and cleanliness. Those suffering most from the containment and other mitigation measures - the at-risk-population, and most likely to be left behind - are usually women, girls and other marginalized groups, such as the elderly, persons living with a disability (PLWD), those living in informal settlements, refugee camps, detention centres, and those in extreme poverty.

SUMMARY In order to prevent and combat the spread of COVID-19, through the WASH First programme, the WASH SDG Consortium partners are scaling up their efforts to improve access to water, sanitation and hygiene (WASH) in the most vulnerable countries. This is done by supporting local communities and governments through information, awareness raising and improved access to WASH services. The overall goal is the promotion of health-related hygiene practices to prevent further spread of COVID-19 in at-risk countries. The WASH First programme is funded by the Ministry of Foreign Affairs (DGIS)/Inclusive Green Growth (IGG) department. Plan International Netherlands is implementing the programme in 4 countries: Indonesia, Uganda, Kenya and Mozambique. The programme started in September 2020 and will run until the end of November 2022.

The WASH First programme aims to enhance understanding of individuals, communities, health workers, schools and WASH service providers about mitigation measures against COVID-19 transmission and provides safe access to water and sanitation services to population at risk. The programme specifically targets the poorest of the poor, women, girls and people with a disability.

The WASH First programme envisages the following categories of interventions in 4 countries: 1. Awareness raising: awareness campaigns and mass media campaigns that make use of inclusive and targeted messaging and communication channels in order to reach those most at risk 2. Direct information sharing and messaging: through home visits, courtyard meetings, community meetings where possible and in line with do-no-harm principles 3. Improving access to safe drinking water and water supply for handwashing, as well as menstrual health and sanitation (including safe disposal of waste), following inclusive designs of facilities and services 4. Improving access to safe handwashing facilities, especially for the most at-risk populations 5. Access to hygiene products including soap, disinfectant, PPE and menstrual hygiene products for the most at-risk target groups 6. COVID-related coordination meetings with local government and other stakeholders to highlight and strengthen the focus on the most marginalized and how to reach them

The WASH First programme focuses on specific objectives targeting high at-risk and most marginalized populations for which a full results framework has been elaborated. Main results in order to reduce the spread of the virus: • Result 1: Enhanced understanding of individuals, communities, health workers, schools and WASH service providers about mitigation measures against COVID-19 transmission • Result 2: Population at risk of COVID-19 have sufficient and constant access to commodities and consumables (handwashing facilities, disinfection equipment, soap, hygiene kits including menstrual health products and personal protective equipment (PPE)) • Result 3: Population at risk of COVID-19 have safe (considering safeguarding and security) access to water and sanitation services through the construction of new and repair of non-functional water and sanitation facilities or through temporary/mobile supplies/services
The WASH First programme envisages the following categories of interventions: 1. Awareness raising: awareness campaigns and mass media campaigns that make use of inclusive and targeted messaging and communication channels in order to reach those most at risk 2. Direct information sharing and messaging: through home visits, courtyard meetings, community meetings where possible and in line with do-no-harm principles 3. Improving access to safe drinking water and water supply for handwashing, as well as menstrual health and sanitation (including safe disposal of waste), following inclusive designs of facilities and services 4. Improving access to safe handwashing facilities, especially for the most at-risk populations 5. Access to hygiene products including soap, disinfectant, PPE and menstrual hygiene products for the most at-risk target groups 6. COVID-related coordination meetings with local government and other stakeholders to highlight and strengthen the focus on the most marginalised and how to reach them

The following principles are, when applicable, incorporated in the WASH First approach: Social sustainability : ensuring that social conditions are realized and sustained so the current and future society is able to create healthy communities. Social sustainable intervention is demand-driven, inclusive (equality), gender equal, culturally sensitive and needs-based. Institutional sustainability : WASH systems, institutions, policies and procedures at the local level are functional and meet the demand of users of WASH services. Environmental sustainability: placing WASH interventions in the wider context of the natural environment and implementing an approach of integrated and sustainable management of water and waste(-water) flows and resources, including the adaptation to climate change. Technical sustainability of WASH services : technology or hardware needed for continuous services is maintained, repaired and replaced by local people and it is not depleting the (natural) resources on which it depends for its functioning. Financial sustainability : continuity in the delivery of products and services related to WASH is assured, because the activities are locally financed (e.g. taxes, local fees, local credit products).

to combat the spread of the virus the WASH SDG Consortium partners are scaling up their efforts to access water, sanitation and hygiene (WASH) in the most vulnerable countries, through the WASH First programme.

THRIVE -Early Childhood Care and Development (including WASH) (ECCD)

title.narrative: WASH SDG Indonesia (including COVID-19 prevention)

description.narrative:
Financial sustainability : The Indonesian Government and the District working groups will be involved during the implementation to ensure the sustainability of the program and guarantee an adequate financial support from the district government. Target for the district government is to issue policy and allocate budget for CLTS (=STBM)-GESI activities. In a bid to build a sense of ownership, communities will be required to contribute a cash contribution based on an appropriate tariff to ensure effective operation and maintenance of water sources. Institutional sustainability: The Indonesian Government is having a strong National CLTS Policy, how ever, with the decentralization of the government, the implementation of national policy on district level is going slow. Plan will conduct capacity building and technical assistance for Sub-district CLTS Team, to encourage district government’s policy to institutionalize GESI-CLTS on their government activities’ planning. The existing monitoring system will be used and will ensure the sustainability of the program. The districts government signed cooperation agreements within 100 pilot villages and 40 pilot schools as a model for replication under the responsibility and funds of the district government. The sustainability compacts will be signed in 2020.
Ecological sustainability: The District Disaster Management Body and the Public Works Agency in the membership of POKJA AMPL will be involved to ensure ecological sustainability of WASH Facilities, by providing guidelines to build WASH facilities that are resilient to disasters and environmentally save. Technical sustainability: The District Disaster Management Body and the Public Works Agency will be involved also to technical sustainability of WASH Facilities, by providing technical guidelines to build WASH facilities that are resilient to disasters and environmentally save.
Social sustainability: Plan will work with the foundations People with Disability to enhance their WASH knowledge, who will then subsequently train government staff on social inclusion. The capacity of the District women groups will be strengthened to enhance their advocacy role toward the WASH working group to promote gender and social inclusion within the WASH policies at the district level. Natural leaders will be engaged in the communities as CLTS Team members assisting in campaigning the behaviour change and monitoring at community level. The school clubs established will promote the participation of the youngest people and enhancing their social inclusion in the local policies.

Pathway 1 : The vision is that 100 pilot communities and 40 pilot schools in the target areas have reached the Open Defecation Free (ODF) status and have moved up the sanitation and hygiene ladder through the use of the GESI STBM approach, within the first two years of the programme. In the third and fourth year of the programme the capacity of the district government is enhanced sufficient to replicate these efforts with funding from the District and City budget (APBD). Women, girls and people with disabilities are empowered This will result in (1) an increased level of participation of those groups in WASH activities in the community, (2) increased levels of shared WASH workload (3) increased level of decision making on WASH in the household and (4) an increase level of leadership positions in communities. Fathers and mothers have also improved their knowledge and practices about baby WASH . In order to make progress towards this Plan will develop a GESI STBM training module. This will be used to train the different WASH Working groups from the Provincial, to the village level. Capacity of these Working groups will also be enhanced on how to promote baby WASH. Plan will also support the establishment of these active groups that are able to lead the implementation of STBM as stipulated in the National STBM Policy. Plan will support District Working groups with the formation of at least 40 sub-district STBM Teams that are active and functioning to assist in implementing STBM in the community. Plan will encourage membership and leadership from women/people with disability in the membership of these working groups. Finally, Plan will use the GWMT to improve and monitor levels of participation of women and socially excluded groups throughout the programme. For further information on these can be found in the inception report (July 2018). Through these tools, men and boys will also be targeted to ensure women and girls are given the space within WASH activities and decision making and the (baby) WASH workload is shared more equally.
Pathway 2: The vision is that the target communities and schools have access to affordable and sustainable products that support attaining all the 5 STBM pillars: 1. Pilar 1: sale of toilet pan, toilet, and inclusive latrine package, and regular faecal sludge emptying service 2. Pilar 2: construction of sink and handwashing tools for kids 3. Pilar 3: water service provision and water filters 4. Pilar 4: provision of community-based waste management services or products 5. Pilar 5: service provision for liquid household waste management (sewer) In order to make progress towards this Plan will conduct a sanitation marketing study to find out which products are currently not available or not affordable in the target areas. Plan will train existing and new entrepreneurs on business and marketing skills in all four target areas and will encourage women and people with disabilities to take a leading role as entrepreneurs or within WASH businesses. New WASH product designs, made by the local entrepreneurs with support of Plan, will be piloted to test if they suit the market in the target areas. Plan will also support the Mataram City government with the formulation of city regulations to prevent illegal dumping of faecal sludge.
Pathway 3: the vision is that the Gender and Social inclusion is reflected in national, provincial and district WASH policies and that the GESI STBM training module is embraced and used by the national, provincial, and district level governments. Women organisations and disability organisations are enabled by the government to participate and hold strategic positions in WASH decision making. National monitoring systems are adjusted to track progress on SDG 6 and national definitions on the WASH ladders have been agreed upon and are contextualized. In order to make progress towards this Plan will support the national government on how to include data on ODF and the other 4 pillars in the online STBM monitoring systems . Through the national WASH working groups, Plan will support the National government with the operationalisation of the SDG’s. Plan will support with the formation of the City/District POKJA AMPL and lobby for city/district policy and adequate budget from the Bupati/Walikota (City/District Head). The active and functioning POKJA AMPL will conduct regular coordination meetings) that involve all members from across the institutions/agencies where they will conduct STBM.

SUMMARY The WASH SDG Project in Indonesia started in July 2017 and is part of the Netherlands WASH SDG Consortium Programme implemented by WASH Alliance International (WAI), SNV and Plan International in Uganda, Ethiopia, Zambia, Tanzania, Indonesia, Bangladesh and Nepal. Plan Indonesia is implementing the project in three districts and one municipality in the East and West Nusa Tenggara provinces. The programme aims to improve access to sanitation for 90,000 rural people and for 551,000 urban people. The programme focuses on improving the position of women, girls and other socially excluded groups. Gender transformative approaches as a part of community led total sanitation activities, sanitation marketing, and demand driven activities will be used to attain the objectives.

The WASH SDG programme-level Theory of Change (ToC) was developed and validated in early 2017. As established in the proposal approved by DGIS, the WASH SDG programme is built on the assumption that sustainable and equitable use of WASH by all can be achieved in a locality through : • Improved behaviour change interventions that lead to increased demand for improved WASH facilities and practices. • Improved WASH service provision that leads to increased availability and affordability of WASH products and services • Strengthened WASH governance and institutional framework that leads to governments enabling efficient and effective delivery of inclusive and sustainable WASH services. In order for WASH to be sustainable and equitable, the programme also assumes that two additional approaches should be endorsed and integrated transversally: • gender transformative and socially inclusive WASH • climate resilient WASH services.

The programme will increase access to sanitation for 150.000 people and hygiene for 229.900 people in selected communities in Malaka and Belu in NTT and Mataram and Lombok in NTB. The selected communities were chosen because access to WASH is limited and a high percentage of the households living in these villages have a low income status.

The programme will support existing Government WASH programmes and is aligned with the project activities of WaterWorX and Blue Deal. Progress on reaching the targets is lagging behind, making it difficult for the government to attain the SDG commitment on reaching 50% safely managed WASH by 2030. Currently Indonesia holds the second highest number of citizens defecating in the open. The WASH activities of the programme will complement the water interventions of the Ministry of Public Works and addresses capacity gaps within the WASH sector at the national, district or city level. Since the SBTM (CLTS) five pillar strategy mainly focusses on attaining ODF, insufficient priority is given to the other pillars: hand washing, drinking treated water, manage household solid and liquid waste; the interests of the people most affected by poor WASH are rarely addressed by government; 15% of all primary schools in Indonesia lack sufficient access to clean water and 54% of all primary schools lack separate toilet for boys and girls; 37% of the children under 5 are stunted. Although the development cooperation programmes of the Dutch Embassy of the Netherlands (EKN) in Indonesia are being phased out gradually close coordination is taking place regarding the WASH SDG project.

The project locations were selected based on criteria of high poverty rates, low access to WAS facilities, low level of MHM knowledge and practices among adolescent girls and high levels of stunting. The poverty of East Nusa Tenggara is characterized by the limited availability and access to educational facilities, health, WASH and food.Because of he lack of water in rural communities of East Nusa Tenggara women, men, and children are spending much time to fetch water for daily use. Although access to water has been improved in the province of West Nusa Tenggara, sanitation and hygiene are still far from improved with almost 50 per cent of people are still not using water and soap for handwashing; 30 per cent of people still consume contaminated water and food and over 60 per cent of the people drink untreated water. Women leadership and participation in the community decision making process remains very low.since Furthermore, people with disabilities and elderly are hardly ever involved in meetings also because public facilities are often not accessible. There is no binding government regulation that directly mandates specific involvement of and fund allocation for women, PWD and the elderly.

Wired4Work! - Technology for YEE Solutions in Indonesia including prevention & response COVID-19

description.narrative:
ILO estimates that 392 million young people have any form of education, employment and training (NEET). Half of those young people live in South Asia, East Asia, and the Pacific. These numbers continue to rise, underlining the urgent need to address global youth unemployment.
Indonesia needs an average of 3.2 million additional skilled workers per year, while budget allocations for non-formal (vocational) education are limited, leaving a significant number of youth untrained. This is reflected in a youth unemployment rate of 17.8%. Approximately 8.7 million women are unemployed compared to 6.1 million men, while poor women are likely to be unpaid workers (27% of women compared to 6% of men).

Plan has secured and allotted funding for at least 10 countries for 2018-2020 to roll out different pieces of the Ecosystem to support programming. But as a key component for the implementation of Plan’s Global Strategic Framework on Youth Employment, Entrepreneurship and Empowerment (YEE), Plan envisions the global adoption of (pieces of the) Ecosystem, with each country office using at least one component for their programs. This will require a comprehensive analysis of the capacities and resources needed to rollout, manage and sustain the effort. Hence, Plan will be undertaking the development of a growth and governance strategy, which would complement the Global Strategic Framework and include the development of a viable business model (e.g. commercial; social enterprise model, such as the open source cooperative; data as an asset; or others) that will guide the organization in securing the resources that will sustain the YES!DIGITAL Ecosystem’s operation and growth.
Plan will target almost 10,300 vulnerable youth (age 16-29 years old), in rural and urban areas of the cities of Jakarta, Semarang and Lombok with a 78% participation of young women.

SUMMARY Over 33 million youth in Asia are struggling to find jobs. Gender inequality is slowing down the transition towards inclusive growth due to women’s limited access to education and employment. In January 2018 Plan International lndonesia started Wired4Work! (W4W). A 3 year innovative Youth Economic Empowerment (YEE) program that leverages scalable digital solutions to increase the capacity of YEE practitioners in reaching youth in high quality employment. W4W is focused on vulnerable youth (16-29 years old), especially women, in Jakarta, Semarang and Lombok, who acquire vocational and work readiness skills to successfully enter the labour market. Also youth are equipped with life skills. By the end of 2020, 10,000 disadvantaged youth will be trained and 3,000 will have access to decent employment.

The following work plan is considered to lead to the targets and outputs of the project:
Component 1: private sector engagement o Conduct a market scan in all implementation areas to determine the labor market trends and opportunities for the target group of vulnerable youth. o Establish agreements with private sector partners to ensure commitment towards hiring youth trained by Plan International, develop traineeship and upskilling opportunities, and create robust mechanisms to link vulnerable youth, particularly young women to opportunities for employment. o Engage with stakeholders to jointly develop market-based and digitally enhanced curricula and training programs. o Create shared value business with companies.
Component 2: Youth skills development and empowerment o Development and scaling up digitally enhanced training modules o Development of a strategy for youth recruitment o Equipping youth with technical and vocational skills o Placement of youth in jobs o Create mechanism for community support for youth
Component 3: o Engage multiple actors/alliances to create an enabling environment for effective youth employment programming. o Offer youth a platform to participate and influence both public and private policy development. o Utilize big data to support and showcase project impact in a reliable, robust and credible way, and to scale up high quality project components and move toward evidence based influence advocacy.
Component 4: o Enhance Alumni engagement by creating a digital platform (or space) which enables students to scale up the network and Capacity building for alumni associations.

Wired4Work is built on assets developed by Plan international since 2011 in alliance with one of its partners from the private sector that has resulted in the training of more than 15,000 youth and the transition of more than 12,000 youth into decent work across Asia and Latin America. These assets include the market scan methodology, YES!ME (direct beneficiary monitoring) system and assessment of high level requirements for e-learning management systems. In multiple strategic partnerships with the Asian Development Bank (ADB) and the World Bank’s Solutions for Youth Employment (S4YE) Coalition, Plan International is working together with other parties of the private and public sector to catalyse new public-private sector partnerships and support new innovative programs for youth economic empowerment.
Plan International Indonesia works in close coordination with the Ministry of Manpower (MoM) and other ministries to replicate the use of the gender-focused life (soft) skills e-learning module across Technical and Vocational Education Training (TVET) institutions. As a result of this strong collaboration with MoM, the life skills modules have been scaled up to 17 vocational training centers (BLKI), sharing resources to improve quality of instructors and management support.

Wired4Work will focus on the following components:
1. Private sector engagement: consisted on the creation of shared value implementation approaches and partnerships with private & public sector actors, training institutions and community-based organizations to increase the job opportunities of youth and develop effective market-driven training curricula to fill in the gap between the offer of trainings and the demand needed in the labour market.
2. Youth skills development and empowerment: Digitally enhanced YEE training solutions are developed, leveraged and scaled to enable vulnerable youth, especially young women, to pursue employment and economic empowerment opportunities. Online modules of the training curricula are developed in the demonstration countries and scaled up to other countries through the YES!ACADEMY (e-learning platform).
3. Enabling environment for youth employment, by strengthening alliances and networks: Through regional and local influence, advocacy and support, this component will facilitate and lead alliances that favour greater inclusion in the labour market for vulnerable youth, especially young women. This component is focused on engaging multiple actors/alliances to create an enabling environment for effective youth employment programming. Plan will also offer youth themselves a platform to participate and influence both public and private policy development.
4. Program quality and innovation to leverage impact The improvement and further development of the YES!DIGITAL Ecosystem of Plan International will bring high quality youth employment initiatives to scale, building capacity of Plan International offices to integrate the Digital Ecosystem assets into their YEE programs, and expanding them with additional services to evolve programs into a full circle digitally enhanced approach. New innovations are developed, especially the YES!CNEXT (match platform for job seekers and companies jobs) using a Human Centered Design approach.
