WASH First: Scaling up WASH SDG efforts: the first line of defence against COVID-19 - Indonesia

description.narrative:
Financial sustainability : Local government and stakeholders have been involved during implementation leading to ownership of the program, especially the district working groups to ensure the sustainability of the program.
Institutional sustainability: Plan will conduct capacity building for Sub-district Community Lead Total Sanitation Teams to encourage district government’s policy to institutionalize GESI-CLTS policy in their own planning.
Ecological sustainability: The District Disaster Management Body and the Public Works Agency in the membership of POKJA AMPL will be involved to ensure sustainability of WASH Facilities, by providing guidelines to build facilities that are resilient to disasters and environmentally save,
Social sustainability: Natural leaders are engaged in the communities assisting in the WASH First at community level. Vulnerable groups such as women, girls, PLWD, the elderly and children, targeted through different channels (schools, community health centres ) have been engaged from the beginning to ensure effective outreach to disability groups is incorporated in the design and implementation. Interventions have been designed to address the needs of girls and women.

Plan International Indonesia has been working in Indonesia since 1969 and in NTT and NTB province long-term child sponsorship programme and a number of grants including the WASH SDG programme are being implemented. These programmes are built on a successful Community led Total Sanitation approach that promotes gender equality and social inclusion. The WASH First programme will build on the capacity and experience of the already existing WASH programmes, which have proven to be successful due to strong partnerships and collaboration with a wide array of government and non-government stakeholders such as POKJA AMPL (Drinking Water and Environmental Health Working Group), the STBM Secretariat, the National AMPL Network, SPEAK, Persani (DPO) YPCII and HAKLI. The programme will be closely aligned with, and scale-up, interventions started under the existing WASH SDG programme, with a modified operational strategy to ensure safety and compliance with the government protocols applicable in the zonal system (red, yellow, green). Existing partnerships with the provincial government of NTB and NTT, district government of West Lombok and city government of Kupang will be strengthened in order to facilitate a rapid start of implementation.

SUMMARY The WASH First programme in Indonesia started in September 2020 and will run until November 2021. It is part of the scaling-up efforts of the WASH SDG Consortium. Its main objective is to prevent further spread of COVID-19. Plan International Indonesia started the implementation in West Lombok District (NTB province) and Kupang City (NTT Province), both neighbouring locations to the ones of the WASH SDG programme. These areas have been hit hard by the pandemic. Plan International Indonesia will 1) Raise awareness of the people living in the target areas on how to prevent the spread of COVID-19, (2) Provide the people living in the target areas with access to hygiene kits (including menstrual hygiene products), disinfected equipment, soap and personal protective equipment to enable them to practice good hygiene practices, (3) improve access to water facilities by rehabilitating water points.

Since the announcement of the first COVID-19 patient in Indonesia on March 2, 2020, the number of people affected by the virus has continued to increase. However the government has not declared a national lockdown. Jakarta is the only region that is implementing large-scale social restrictions consisting of a period of restriction to the return of socio-economic activities that benefit the wider community. In the NTB Province, one of the program locations, up to 30 October 2020 there are 3,950 positive patients with COVID-19 and 219 deaths. In the province of NTT the number of positive cases in NTT is 679, 7 of which have died. The COVID-19 pandemic exposed underlying inequalities and has exacerbated the situation of the most marginalized groups, including women and girls. Everyday barriers consist of physical accessibility, barriers to implementing basic hygiene measures, affordability of healthcare, limitations on health insurance and discriminatory laws and stigma. The marginalized groups are often excluded from communications on public health, decision making and information on accessibility of basic services, resulting into a limited understanding of risks and the ability to carry out preventive measures .

The activities per intervention strategies are the following:
1: Awareness raising (campaigns and mass media campaigns) on COVID-19 Gender sensitive and socially inclusive awareness-raising will be used to expand public outreach campaigns and support for community-based COVID-19 transmission prevention through STBM-MHM: • Develop of inclusive IEC/BCC materials on STBM-MHM and COVID-19 (including short film production) • Produce a STBM-MHM public campaign (involving local leaders, religious leaders, government officials, influencers, public figures) through different channels (radio, social media, local/national TV)
2: Direct information sharing and messaging • Strengthen the community volunteers’ capacity (posyandu volunteers, ECCD teachers, CBCPM committee/parenting class facilitators) on gender sensitive and socially inclusive STBM-MHM and COVID-19 training • Support the implementation of STBM-MHM and COVID-19 IPC in the local community centres (ECCD and parenting class centres) • Strengthen the capacity of local leaders, community volunteers and local health workers on COVID-19 protocols and inclusive STBM-MHM • Provide behavioural change training for teachers, peer educators and student-parent committees to implement inclusive STBM-MHM and safe back-to-school procedures • Implement campaigns on child-friendly, inclusive and COVID-19 preventive STBM-MHM in schools • Conduct webinar to share best practice of inclusive and STBM-MHM in schools during the pandemic
3: Improving access to safe drinking water and water supply for handwashing, as well as menstrual health and sanitation (including safe disposal of waste) • Rehabilitate of WASH facilities in puskesmas (using a human-centred design approach to ensure universal and inclusive access that includes DPOs) • Strengthen gender and socially inclusive WASH in health care facilities (HCFs) to allow continued safe operation and safeguard health workers and service users • Promote gender and socially inclusive WASH in schools and inclusive MHM to support school transition and anticipate safe re-opening • Provide hardware that is accessible in health care facilities, posyandu, schools and early childhood education centres • Strengthen the capacity of community health centre (puskesmas) workers on safely managed sanitation and HCF-based infectious COVID-19 solid waste management • Socialisation and online-offline training on repurposing BOS (School Operational Fund) for STBMMHM in schools with a prior advocacy and engagement with the local district/city office for education (dikbud)
4 and 5: Improving access to safe handwashing facilities: Access to hygiene products such as soap, disinfectant, PPE and menstrual hygiene products Access to safe handwashing facilities and hygiene products and sufficient and constant access to commodities and consumables such as handwashing facilities, disinfection equipment, soap, hygiene kits including menstrual health products and PPE will be achieved through: • Distribution of PPE and hygiene kits for health care facilities • Development of IEC/BCC materials on inclusive COVID-19 IPC for HCF • Access to hygiene and MHM kits for marginalised groups • Distribution of PPE and hygiene supplies and MHM kit for schools and madrasahs (soap, reusable menstrual pads, disinfectant, face shields, transparent cubicles, non-medical masks) Intervention strategy
6: COVID-related coordination meetings with local government and other stakeholders In the STBM approach, government capacity building is very important to ensure sustainability. The enabling environment component is also written in the Theory of Change of the WASH SDG subprogramme. As this proposed new programme aims as far as possible to replicate best practices from the this programme, the following institutional capacity building strategies will also contribute to this new programme. Develop a guidebook on the implementation of gender sensitive and inclusive STBM-MHM, in collaboration with AMPL working groups, the Ministry of Health and the Ministry of Education and Culture 2. Train for inclusive budgeting (for STBM-MHM and COVID-19) for village government and district/city governments officials 3. Offer technical capacity building for local government officials (AMPL working group, COVID-19 task force) to implement STBM-MHM in the target district/city 4. Hold regular coordination meetings with district/city stakeholders for improved implementation of STBM-MHM

The overall goal is the promotion of health-related hygiene practices to prevent further spread of COVID-19 in at-risk countries through awareness raising and improved access to WASH services. It aligns fully with the WASH SDG programme that is working towards enhancing sustainable and equitable access to and use of WASH for all. This programme will focus on specific objectives focusing on high at-risk and most marginalised populations (for which a full results framework has been developed). :• Result 1: Enhanced understanding of individuals, communities, health workers, schools and WASH service providers about mitigation measures against COVID-19 transmission • Result 2: Population at risk of COVID-19 have sufficient and constant access to commodities and consumables (handwashing facilities, disinfection equipment, soap, hygiene kits including menstrual health products and personal protective equipment (PPE)) • Result 3: Population at risk of COVID-19 have safe (considering safeguarding and security) access to water and sanitation services through the construction of new and repair of non-functional water and sanitation facilities or through temporary/mobile supplies/services

The programme intends to reach 350,000 people, including poor families, child-headed households (or girl-married households), female-headed households, families with nursing mothers and families with people living with disability or elderly members. Families who have a member(s) under COVID-19 surveillance, who have been confirmed infected will also be included in the target beneficiaries.222

title.narrative: Yes I Do Zambia incl COVID-19 prevention

description.narrative: Deep-rooted norms and expectations about girls and boys make families and communities feel the need to control the sexuality of girls by marrying them off. Gender inequality is putting girls in a subordinate position with regard to boys and men in (sexual) relationships. For example, girls cannot refuse to have unprotected sex and this is resulting in a high level of teenage pregnancies. Girls and boys lack a voice, as well as the support to break through these norms and practices. The means and structures available for adolescents to organise themselves and claim their rights are limited and they have little access to adolescent-friendly and good quality SRHR information and services. There are close links between EM and teenage pregnancies and girls' lack of education. Indeed, girls’ access to education is very restricted, which makes it difficult for them to find jobs later. It also hampers their economic independence. Legislation to outlaw EM is either inadequate or is being poorly implemented.

EM and teenage pregnancies mutually reinforce one another. Social and gender norms perpetuating EM are deeply embedded in communities and this situation can only be changed if community leaders and most of the people, including boys and men, support the change. Key persons in the communities, including boys and men, will be turned into allies in the process of changing these norms, thereby helping to address the problem of EM and teenage pregnancies. A general lack of information about SRHR and poor quality and access to the relevant services are perpetuating the above-mentioned problems. Adolescent boys and girls are being informed about SRHR and given a voice to claim these rights. Girls are being given more control over their lives. This is being achieved by changing these norms and people’s behaviour, strengthening networks and structures for social mobilisation and embedding these in communities, and by involving the government and the private sector in improving SRHR and services. All these will help to reduce EM and teenage pregnancies.
Final beneficiaries are girls between the age of 12 – 24 years, married and unmarried.

SUMMARY Millions of adolescent girls all over the world are facing a limited future because of early marriage (EM) and teenage pregnancies. With this project, by changing the attitude of community members and other key persons and informing adolescent girls and boys, adolescents will be empowered to stand up for their sexual reproductive health and rights (SRHR). Through education and economic empowerment, supported by the relevant legislation and policies, the project will give adolescents alternatives beyond EM and teenage pregnancies. The project will be implemented between 2016 and 2020 by Plan International Nederland, together with partners Rutgers, Choice, KIT and the Netherlands’ Embassy (located in in Harare, Zimbabwe). Next to Zambia, similar projects under the same framework will be carried out in Ethiopia, Kenya, Malawi, Mozambique, Indonesia and Pakistan.

Sustainability will be achieved a.o. through strengthening of local CSOs, involvement of and cooperation with key stakeholders including local government representatives, community and religious leaders and private partners. Key research gaps will be identified with the key stakeholders and direct beneficiaries and will be addressed to improve evidence based lobby and advocacy towards preventing CM and TP. Further strategies to enhance sustainability will be developed in the course of the project implementation.

This programme is a follow up of the Plan regional EM programme (18+) in Malawi, Zambia and Mozambique, in which adolescents are being trained as agents of change to make their voice heard in claiming their SRH rights. The programme is being implemented by the Yes I Do alliance in which each partner is adding value by implementing part of one or more of the intervention strategies.

Throughout the project, different trainings will be given to influence the attitudes and behaviour of parents and community and religious leaders, as harmful practices such as EM and teenage pregnancies are deeply rooted in social norms. Plan supports the building of a social movement aimed at transforming these harmful social and gender norms. Community members from different backgrounds and of different ages who are the gatekeepers will be stimulated to engage in dialogue in relation to these practices, together with young people. The programme will create an enabling environment for young people and, particularly, support boys and girls who, based on their new knowledge, take action and, for example, influence service providers on SRHR.
Also different activities focusing on improving access to adolescent SRHR information and Comprehensive Sexuality Education will take place. Actions for improvement of the access to adolescent SRH and child protection services will be undertaken by for instance training health staff, teachers and peer educators. The capacity of health care providers will be built to deliver quality and youth-friendly SRH services. As a result of these activities, the project will ensure that young people are referred to the SRH services they need and can take informed action on their SRHR.
Also, the project will seek opportunities for girls to stay in school and develop economic prospects. Enrollment in secondary education is enhanced sensitizing activities for parents, teachers and the community that educating girls will benefit the entire family and the community. Parents and school teachers will be made aware of the positive correlation between education and EM and teenage pregnancies. By involving the private sector, the programme will provide opportunities to adolescent girls to gain access to a business network. Besides economic empowerment through education, the programme will also directly work towards girls’ economic empowerment by increasing their access to credit and income-generating activities through village saving and loan associations. It will help young women acquire entrepreneurial skills and access financial and business advisory services to enable them to start their own business.
Through lobby and advocacy activities the project will motivate policymakers and duty bearers to put EM and teenage pregnancies, and adolescent SRHR issues in general, high on the political agenda, by increasing their awareness and understanding of the issues and their role as duty bearers.

title.narrative: % boys aged 15-24 who ever received education about sexuality and sexual health

description.narrative: A community-based cluster sample survey was administered at the household level among young girls and boys aged 15-24 in the intervention areas (Chadiza&Petauke) and control area (Katete). The survey included question about child marriage. We obtained a sample size of 1434 using a standard formula- taking into account possible “design effects” because of the clustered sampling- we multiplied the required sample by 1.5 and had a ratio of 75% female respondents and 25% male respondents. A total of 1455 questionnaires were administered.

comment.narrative: % boys aged 15-24 who ever received education about sexuality and sexual health

description.narrative: For humanitarian projects up to 12 months Plan International Netherlands uses the gender with age marker of IASC (https://www.iascgenderwithagemarker.com). 1 = key programme actions do not address gender or age differences 2= addresses only age differences 3= addresses only gender differences 4 = addresses gender & age differences

WASH SDG Zambia (including COVID-19 prevention)

description.narrative: FIETS criteria: Financial: Improvement of sanitation based on local resources has a positive effect on the local economy. The use of nutrients will provide fertilizer for food production. Institutional: Lusaka Water and Sewerage will take full control and ownership over the sanitation system and involve the private sector. In addition, government must be willing and able to support the private sector and guarantee the legality of the system owners and operators. Environmental: The sanitation approach is based on the principle of closing the loop with respect to nutrient and water use for improved food security. Minimising water use for toilet flushing by introduction of (semi-) dry sanitation systems will minimise ground and surface water pollution. This will have a positive effect on the drinking water quality. Technical: The proposed technologies are based on a dry sanitation approach combined with the collection of urine, faeces and/or sludge, to be treated and used in agricultural applications. Because the system is simple and adjustable to local standards its principles are replicable in almost every situation. Social: By including also the poor and provide them affordable services, the programme guarantees social inclusion.

On recommendation of the Ministry of Water Development, Sanitation and Environment Protection the districts of Kafue and Chongwe were selected because of the major problems in the field of WASH, as was also the outcome of the Water and Sanitation Sector Report of 2016. Women’s low level participation in decision making at household level is affected by their inadequate contribution to household income which hinders negotiation for gender friendly sanitation facilities. The program has the potential for scaling up and provide access to sanitation for the whole district. Achieving full coverage is possible since the district has experience in implementing total sanitation approaches at district and sub-district level because of previous project supported by Unicef. This project was implemented in the rural areas. The buy-in and acceptance of programme by the district stakeholders such as government and line ministries, including the traditional leadership and communities, guarantees long-term sustainability of the programme activities.

Pathway 1: The vision of the sub-programme for this pathway by the end of the programme, is to have improved rural and peri-urban WASH services in the two selected districts by bringing together relevant stakeholders like finance institutes, retailers, service providers, local builders and Community Based Enterprises. By strengthening the sanitation value chain, WASH services will be improved for approx. 21,000 households of the Bottom Of the Pyramid. Consumers in the target communities will have access to sanitary pads, soap, water filter, water container, toilet pan and latrine slabs at an affordable price. To make progress towards this, Plan will work together with local stakeholders like government, WASH committees and Champions for Change. The SP will strengthen the capacity of local government in implementing (Urban) Community Led Total Sanitation (UCLTS) with focus on Nutrition Sensitive Hygiene and Sanitation, hand washing and elimination of open defecation. By training government staff the SP will stimulate reproduction of the activities in other districts. The role of Champions for Change is very relevant and they will be selected from local influencers like traditional leaders, community workers and youth. Pathway 2: The vision of the programme for this pathway by the end of the programme is to have improved rural and peri-urban WASH services in the two selected districts by bringing together relevant stakeholders like finance institutes, retailers, service providers, local builders and Community Based Enterprises. By strengthening the sanitation value chain, WASH services will be improved for approx. 21,000 households of the Bottom Of the Pyramid. Consumers in the target communities will have access to sanitary pads, soap, water filter, water container, toilet pan and latrine slabs at an affordable price. The programme will focus on the capacity building and orientation of local service providers on best-fit practices for delivering household-level sanitation services, including a combination of marketing, construction, product sales, financial management, and regulatory conformance skills to (female) entrepreneurs. To make this possible, Micro Finance Institutions will be involved so they can offer the necessary loans to the enterprises. Local saving groups will be setup or strengthened so they can provide households with the necessary financing to install their own sanitation facilities. Pathway 3: The vision of the sub-programme for this pathway by the end of the programme, is that new and existing local government committees (WASHCO’s)will have been strengthened, while the government action plans on WASH will have improved. At the district level, gender transformation and social inclusion is mainstreamed in all WASH programmes and sufficient budget is allocated to implement these programmes.In order to make progress towards this vision the SP will focus on dialogue and cooperation with relevant government entities in order to not only strengthen capacity of local government, but also to achieve that WASH policies and guidelines will facilitate the necessary investments and acceleration of WASH sector development and scaling-up. SP promotes representation of at least 50% women and socially excluded in these governance structures. Together with local government, SP will improve action plans focusing on WASH service delivery at community level. Together with government Plan will organize joint national communication campaigns to promote the importance of WASH and so further increasing demand creation.

SUMMARY The WASH SDG Programme in Zambia started in 2017 and is part of the Netherlands WASH SDG Consortium Programme which is implemented by WASH Alliance International (WAI), SNV and Plan International. Plan International Zambia started implementing the WASH SDG programme in two districts, Chongwe rural and the peri-urban areas of Chongwe and Kafue. Zambia did not meet the MDG target of 70% access to improved sanitation by 2015. The programme will increase access to sanitation and hygiene for 161,882 and to water for 5,300 people. It also aims at improving the position of women, girls and other socially excluded groups. The programme will focus on sanitation and hygiene, targeting a total of 41,556 people going up the sanitation ladder. The programme targets a total of 85,425 people regarding safe hygiene practices (e.g. handwashing). The water supply support is targeting 5,250 people in rural Chongwe.

The WASH SDG programme-level Theory of Change (ToC) was developed and validated in early 2017. To achieve the vision of the WASH SDG through the Theory of Change, Plan will have three pathways. • improved behaviour change interventions that lead to increased demand for improved WASH facilities and practices • improved WASH service provision that leads to increased availability and affordability of WASH products and services • strengthened WASH governance and institutional framework that leads to governments enabling efficient and effective delivery of inclusive and sustainable WASH services. In order for WASH to be sustainable and equitable, the programme also assumes that two additional approaches should be endorsed and integrated transversally: • gender transformative and socially inclusive WASH • climate resilient WASH services.

The target group consists of 162.882 beneficiaries.
Chongwe rural: 87.600 beneficiaries Chongwe urban: 15.889 beneficiaries Kafue urban: 59.393

Zambia has an estimated population of 15 million, with 75% under the poverty line. The quickly expanding urban areas as well as rural areas are characterised by low access to basic services including schools, health centres, safe water supply and sanitation. Climate change causes unpredictable rainfall, drought, floods and a rise of temperature which affects livelihood of people. Zambia did not meet the MDG target of 70.5% access, nationally, to improved sanitation by 2015. Some two thirds of the rural population still do not have access to an improved household toilet. The country continues to experience waterborne disease problems. In Chongwe and Kafue, districts of the project area 53% of the water supply is safely managed. 86% of the health facilities have basic water supply service level. Only 1% of the households have a safely managed toilet. Most toilets were pit latrines In Chongwe 54,4% of toilets were unimproved . All the schools have their own toilets on the premises, but almost all exceed the national standard for pupil toilet ratios. Women have low level of participation in decision making at household level. Limited levels of education among women continue to limit their participation in WASH activities..

(DRA) Dutch Nigeria Joint Response 2020

description.narrative: In 2020, the North-East Nigeria crisis is going into it’s eleventh year. Even though the number of people in need has decreased from 7.7 to 7.1 million between June 2018 and June 2019, the crisis remains one of the most severe in the world. Continued widespread insecurity and hostilities, especially in Borno State, continue to have serious consequences on humanitarian operations and the civilian population.

The NJR2020 programme will support the first two strategic objectives outlined in the Humanitarian Response Strategy 2019 -2021 for Nigeria. In line with strategic objective 1 ‘To save lives and alleviate suffering through integrated and coordinated humanitarian response focusing on the most vulnerable people’, the NJR2020 partners will provide life-saving activities in the sectors of Food Security and Livelihoods (FSL), Multi-Purpose Cash (MPC), Protection, Nutrition and WASH, with a small Health component implemented in one location. In line with strategic objective 2 ‘to enhance access to humanitarian assistance and protection services through principled humanitarian action’ the NJR partners will ensure strong community engagement and mainstream gender and protection concerns in their interventions to ensure equitable and meaningful access to services.

The intervention will continue to focus on vulnerable children and households amongst IDPs, returnees and host communities, in particular child-headed households, women-headed households, Pregnant and Lactating Women, elderly and people with special needs.

title.narrative: (DRA) Nigeria Joint Response 2021

description.narrative: In the past year, the humanitarian needs in North-East Nigeria have exacerbated immensely due to increased hostilities and COVID-19. Attacks by AOGs and military operations across the northeast continue to result in increased displacement, humanitarian needs and food insecurity. The number of people in need had increased from 7.7 to 7.9 million between 2019 and 2020 due to increased violence and insecurity. On top of that the number of people in need rose steeply from 7.9 to 10.6 million people mid-2020 due to the outbreak of COVID-19 .

Similar to 2019 and 2020, the NJR2021 programme will support the first two strategic objectives outlined in the Humanitarian Response Strategy 2019 -2021 for Nigeria. In line with strategic objective 1 ‘To save lives and alleviate suffering through integrated and coordinated humanitarian response focusing on the most vulnerable people’, the NJR2020 partners will provide life-saving activities in the sectors of Food Security and Livelihoods (FSL), Multi-Purpose Cash (MPC), Health, Protection and WASH. COVID-19 prevention measures will be mainstreamed across all sectors. The NJR will no longer provide a nutrition response as the number of people in need in the nutrition sector is 1,1 million according to the 2020 HNO which is a decrease of more than 50% compared to the 2019-2021 HRP for Nigeria . In line with strategic objective 2 ‘to enhance access to humanitarian assistance and protection services through principled humanitarian action’ the NJR partners will ensure strong community engagement and mainstream gender, disability inclusion and protection concerns in their interventions to ensure equitable and meaningful access to services.

title.narrative: Improving Prospects for Refugees and Vulnerable Host Communities in Lebanon – Budget Reprogramming for Covid-19 Response

description.narrative: Protect the most vulnerable children and communities from infection, to slow down the transmission, alongside the secondary impacts of non-COVID-19 related to basic needs and protection.

The Government of Lebanon declared a state of emergency in response to the COVID-19 pandemic on the 15th of March 2020. The situation is compounded because of the layering of the pandemic onto the ongoing economic and political instability experienced over the course of 2019 and into 2020. The combination of the three means that Lebanon faces a particularly difficult challenge in supporting displacement-affected populations in the short- but also into the medium- and longer-term, as the country deals with these crises and recovers from them. This programme will expand the integrated approach to provide services to children exposed to all forms of child protection violations including all forms of abuse, violence, exploitation and neglect resulting from the COVID-19 response measures and promote a more protective environment for children to prevent violations. This programme will also address the immediate basic needs of families during this emergency phase and support local authorities to adequately prepare for the coronavirus outbreak.

The activities target Syrian and Palestinian refugees, and vulnerable Lebanese host community children (all ages), adolescents (girls and boys aged 14-17 including those with disabilities) and adults in urban areas in the greater Beirut area, focusing on the most vulnerable groups.

South Sudan Joint Response 2021 - programme

description.narrative: Although the recently revitalized peace Agreement (R-ARCSS) offers a new glimpse of hope and stability in South Sudan with recent formation of Transitional Government of National Unity (TGoNU), the cumulative effects of years of protracted conflict, violence, underdevelopment, lack of basic services, economic crisis, and climatic shocks have continued to exacerbate the humanitarian situation in the country, with millions people living in precarious conditions of abject poverty, chronic food insecurity and malnutrition, and economic destitution.

Save the Children will continue implementing an integrated multi-sector project to respond to the increasing humanitarian needs. The action seeks to implement a holistic, multi-sectoral approach to the most affected population and support their recovery in the short to medium term. The project will particularly contribute to the 2020 HRP strategic objectives SO2: facilitate safe, equitable and dignified access to critical cross-sectoral basic services to enable populations meet their basic needs in locations of severity levels 3 and 4 and SO3: enable vulnerable people to recover from crisis, seek solutions to displacement and build resilience to acute shocks and chronic stresses through targeted programming to support coping capacities and livelihoods in prioritized areas;

The complex context, exacerbated by floods, COVID-19, economic hardships, and conflict have continued to exacerbate existing vulnerabilities , with disproportionate impact on the host communities, IDPs and returnees. Therefore, the target group for the SSJR 2021 will continue to target the most vulnerable households amongst IDPS, returnees and host communities, with a particular focus on child-headed households, female headed households, PLW, elderly, households with children facing SAM/MAM, malnourished children, youth, vulnerable adolescent boys and girls. In 2021, SSJR partners will continue the conscious effort to ensure People with Disabilities (PWD) are included.

DRA South Sudan COVID JR - Coordination

description.narrative:
At the Netherlands level, the ‘day-to-day’ support to the DRA COVID JR in South Sudan is handled by humanitarian staff from Save the Children, who are responsible for (i.e.): resolving any arising issues during implementation of the programme which require consultation and resolution at the Netherlands level; maintaining contact with the DRA Committee, the Ministry of Foreign Affairs and the partner NGO main offices; maintaining contact with the field coordination team in South Sudan; consolidating reporting to the Ministry of Foreign Affairs; organizing the meta-audit; and contributing to visibility to the Ministry but also the Dutch public.
In South Sudan, the day-to-day management of the programme is handled by the Field Coordinator, who is responsible for (i.e.): monitoring the overall programme implementation (by consulting, meetings, field visits); resolving any arising issues during implementation of the program; representing partners and relevant stakeholders; maintaining contact with UN(OCHA); maintaining contact with the Lead in the Netherlands; supporting cooperation amongst the partners and coordination, investigate opportunities to generate added value; organizing the evaluation; generating visibility and taking forward issues for joint lobby & advocacy towards key stakeholders

title.narrative: Desert Locust Joint Response - Somalia

description.narrative: A locust invasion in Somalia is threatening livelihoods as crops and vegetation for livestock foraging suffer extensive damage. According to the Somaliland National Disaster Preparedness and Food Reserve Authority (NADFOR) localized damage has been observed in Somaliland, where locusts have occupied a total of 100,000ha of Somaliland’s coastal region including Woqooyi Galbeed. This has affected1,087,264 people, of which 22,853 are in IDPs camps. SC has observed the impact of the locust invasion to be most severe in Hargeisa Maroodijeh with 8,000ha of rangeland and 3,000ha of crop land damaged. In addition, Agabar and Arbasiyo villages in Gabiley districts have also been hard-hit with 1,000ha of damaged land. The Woqooyi Galbeed region was already characterized by significant food security gaps which is exacerbated by the desert locust crisis. According to the FSNAU technical release 153,000 people are food insecure (IPC 3 or 4) including 12,054 in Gabiley district and 139,134 in Hargeisa district. An SC survey showed that pastoralists are skipping meals or selling their remaining livestock for low prices to purchase food. There is also an increasing trend of labor migration at the critical time of Gu seasonal preparation. Only few actors respond to the locust crisis in this area including SOS and World Vision. Response gaps affirmed by the Food Security Cluster (FSC) monthly dashboard show 150,000 people need urgent Multi-Purpose Cash (MPC) support to protect access to food security. These include IDPs and pastoralists who have lost their livestock and have less than 6 goats. In addition to the locust crisis, Somalia is also at risk of an outbreak of the COVID-19 virus. Somalia reported its first confirmed case of COVID-19 on 16th March 2020 and currently has 60 recorded cases including 5 in Somaliland and 2 in Woqooyi Galbeed. Given the rapid pace of the virus and lack of access to testing kits, there are concerns that the number of cases will rise rapidly.

SC will support 700 households (HH) including IDPs in (agro)pastoralist communities with MPC transfers of 95 USD for three months to increase their purchasing power to meet their basic needs. In addition, SC will expand Infection Prevention and Control (IPC) and Risk Communication and Community Engagement (RCCE) under an ongoing Integrated Community Case Management (ICCM) programme to mitigate the risk of COVID-19.

Dutch NGO’s Joint Humanitarian Response for South Sudan COVID-19 Joint Response

description.narrative:
The COVID-19 pandemic is spreading rapidly in South Sudan. The COVID-19 crisis in South Sudan is more than a national health emergency. In South Sudan, from April 6 to August 31st, 2020, there have been 2.527 confirmed cases of COVID-19 with 47 deaths . While the number of cases in South Sudan might seem low, limited testing and social stigma obscure the true magnitude of the pandemic .
The COVID-19 outbreak in South Sudan comes against the backdrop of an already dire humanitarian situation. People’s access to basic services was very limited already before the outbreak, and COVID-19 related restrictions on movement and service provision have only made the situation worse. 56 per cent of the nearly 12 million population in South Sudan does not have access to primary health care services. Out of approximately 2,300 health facilities, more than 1,300 are non-functional .

The DRA partners have designed their response based on needs and gaps in line with HRP COVID-19 addendum and the National Action Plan, and in line with their technical expertise and complementarity with other interventions to maximize impact. In line with FSL Cluster recommendations, DRA partners will support vulnerable households, including households with suspected or confirmed COVID cases, with emergency life-saving food assistance, and complement with livelihood and livestock support in order to address immediate and longer term needs. The DRA partners will implement a WASH program which focuses primarily on containing the spread of COVID-19 pandemic and decrease morbidity and mortality, outlined as the first strategic objective of the COVID-19 addendum to the HRP. DRA partners will ensure the provision of critical protection related assistance and specialized services in all targeted locations. DRA partners aim to contribute to the specific objectives of the Health Cluster, supporting in containing the spread of the COVID-19 outbreak and avoid excess morbidity and mortality.
The DRA partners will target both host and IDP communities, as well as returnees, to ensure a conflict-sensitive approach.

title.narrative: (DRA) Dutch South Sudan Joint Response 2021

description.narrative: According to the 2020 Humanitarian Needs Overview (HNO), some 7.5 million people remain in need humanitarian assistance. More than half of South Sudan’s population were expected to face acute food insecurity at the height of the annual hunger season between May and July, according to projections made before the impacts of COVID-19, the plummeting oil prices and the recent desert locust infestation on food security were anticipated. With COVID-19 and related food price hikes, some 1.6 million people have become newly vulnerable due to their dependence on markets . Latest FEWSNET reports from September 2020 indeed indicate that the scale and severity of food insecurity in South Sudan from October 2020 through January 2021 is expected to remain among the highest recorded since 2014, with crisis outcomes (IPC Phase 3) are likely in 25 counties .

SSJR will focus on vulnerable households amongst IDPS, returnees and host communities, with a particular focus of FSL, WASH and MPC interventions targeting child-headed households, female headed households, PLW, elderly, households with children facing SAM/MAM, and people with disabilities. Vulnerable youth and adolescent boys and girls are specifically targeted in specific Protection activities as well.

The SSJR program will continue to provide life-saving assistance and aim to enhance the transition from humanitarian assistance to resilience programming, addressing root causes, enabling vulnerable and at-risk communities to build resilience to acute shocks and chronic stresses, and recover from crisis. Lastly, the SSJR program will continue to address critical problems relating to physical and mental wellbeing, strongly reinforcing protection throughout the program, both integrated within other sectors, and as a separate sector.
The SSJR 2021 will continue to contribute to all 2020 HRP strategic objectives: • Reduce morbidity and mortality, as well as suffering from protection threats and incidents • Facilitate safe, equitable and dignified access to critical cross-sectoral basic services to enable populations meet their basic needs, and • Enable vulnerable people to recover from crisis, seek solutions to displacement and build resilience to acute shocks and chronic stresses through targeted programming to support coping capacities and livelihoods.
In line with the strategic objective of the COVID-19 addendum HRP, SSJR 2021 program will support efforts in containing and preventing the spread of COVID-19 while employing a COVID-19 adapted approach to respond to the ongoing emergency.

title.narrative: Love Alliance

description.narrative:
Across Africa, communities are strengthened to come together and build movements to advocate for change by identifying common issues and tackling them together. Community organisations receive funding and support to fight for their rights and promote access to SRHR. The Love Alliance seeks to significantly reduce HIV infections by influencing policies, raising awareness and organising communities in ten African countries. With a specific focus on people who use drugs, sex workers, LGBTIQ+ people and people living with HIV, we aim to achieve the following goals:
1. Capable, inclusive, influential, and mutually supportive key population movements in unrestricted civic space. 2. An end to sexual, gender-based violence, stigma and discrimination against key populations. 3. Equal access to inclusive, people-centred, accountable, integrated HIV and comprehensive sexual and reproductive health services.
Our strategic objectives contribute to the Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs) 3 and 5 and result areas 4 and 1 of the Dutch Ministry of Foreign Affairs’ SRHR strategy.

The Love Alliance is based on the premise that to end AIDS, the groups most affected by the epidemic need to be at the centre of the response. We build on existing evidence on the effectiveness of rights-based responses that focus on and meaningfully engage LGBTQI people, sex workers, people who use drugs, with specific attention for people living with HIV, women and young people within these communities.

The Love Alliance, a new five-year programme (2021-2025), is based on an unwavering commitment to protecting, promoting and fulfilling sexual and reproductive health and rights (SRHR) globally, unifying people who use drugs, sex workers and LGBTQI movements, and amplifying the diversity of voices in these communities.
The alliance brings together national thought leaders GALZ, SANPUD and Sisonke, regional grantmakers UHAI EASHRI, AFE and ISDAO, with the global network of people living with HIV (GNP+) and the Netherlands-based administrative lead Aidsfonds.
Together, we advocate for adequate levels of funding and for taking truly human rights-based programmes to scale. We take this opportunity to prioritise and invest in challenging the structural barriers of underfunding, criminalisation and exclusion of us in all our diversity.

The world is far behind in preventing new HIV infections. In 2019, 1.7 million people were newly infected with the virus, more than three times the global target. Also, the response could be set even further back, by a decade or more, if the COVID-19 pandemic results in severe disruptions to HIV services.
In 2019, people who use drugs, LGBTQI people and sex workers accounted for 62% of new HIV infections worldwide, an increase of 15% compared to 2018. Causes for this increase are stigma and discrimination, together with other social inequalities and exclusion. Despite the urgency and needs, only 2% of current global HIV financing goes to programming for these key populations, and even less goes directly to communities and their organisations. There is an urgent need for securing the sexual and reproductive health and rights of all people.

sector.narrative: Love Alliance STD control including HIV/AIDS

title.narrative: 2020 SY4019 * NW Syria Covid -19 Response

description.narrative: In this project War Child and local implementing partner, IYD, will distribute one-off hygiene kits to 3400 families in Northwest Syria in Idleb (Idlib and Harim district) in order to equip families to take precautions against contracting COVID-19. In line with the most recent WASH cluster guidelines (of which War Child is a member and IYD is the NGO co-lead), these kits have been tailored to make these appropriate for prevention of COVID-19 infection. In addition to the distribution of kits, IYD will conduct RCCE on hygiene promotion and the identification of symptoms of COVID-19.

Desert Locust Joint Response in Ethiopia and Somalia (DLJR)

description.narrative: provide life-saving assistance to people facing severe food insecurity. The design of the intervention is based on the sectors directly related to the locust infestation (FSL + MPC), in line with the cluster recommendations, based on the expertise of partners and complementarity with other ongoing interventions. The intervention will target the most vulnerable HHs, to improve direct access to food, protect and rebuild livelihoods, which contributes to the structural approach addressing the infestation. All responses are adapted to the current COVID-19 pandemic, and activities are carried out in a way to minimise risk to both staff and beneficiaries and reduce the spread. Most interventions incorporate activities to raise awareness on hygiene and disease prevention, and in some cases respond directly with additional Health and WASH interventions. Partners will work in rural as well as urban areas, depending on the locally identified needs. Across all areas, relevant cluster, SPHERE, and CHS standards are followed.

activity-date.narrative: The project has two major results corresponding to the aforementioned specific objectives. These are: • Result-1: Livelihood impacts of the DL infestation in Deka Suftu and Moyale woredas adequately understood and longer-term actions recommended identified • Result-2: The livelihood statuses of 117 DL-affected households in Moyale woreda improved Project activities Activities under Result-1: • Conduct DL impact (and market) assessment in Deka Suftu and Moyale woredas • Identify recommendations for a longer-term livelihood development in the area Activities under Result-1: • Set a set of criteria and select 117 households to benefit from the multipurpose cash • Establish and orient project steering committee • Train selected DAE staff and key government staff on multi-purpose cash distribution • Conduct cash distribution • Conduct monthly participatory reviews

job-title.narrative: Programme Strategic Advisory and Humanitarian Expert

recipient-country.narrative: In its February 20, 2020 update, the Food and Agricultural Organization of the United Nations (FAO) declared that the Desert Locust infestation problem had covered eight countries in East Africa, namely Ethiopia, Kenya, Somalia, Djibouti, Eritrea, and lately, Uganda, Tanzania, and South Sudan. The situation has been described to be of an alarming status for Ethiopia, Somalia, and Kenya, where it is feared to have potentially threatened the countries’ food security and livelihood systems. The crisis has been rated to be the worst in 25 years for Ethiopia, although it has spread and damaged further more since. In the last 20 days in Ethiopia, the numbers of regions and districts affected by the DL have increased from 6 to 7 and from 153 to 173, respectively, thereby further threatening the country’s cash crop and bread basket areas. Region wise, only Gambella and Benishangul Gumuz regions have remained unaffected. Observations on the ground show that the DL infestation must have caused large-scale damages on the performance of the country’s livestock and crop production as well as on its forest coverage, thereby worsening food security situations. Areas so far affected by the DL roughly overlap with woredas already experiencing chronic food insecurity, and hence targets for the humanitarian response plan (HRP).

sector.narrative: Food security and livelihoods 30% of the budget will go to FSL. Depending on the local circumstances, food security interventions will be done either through food/cash vouchers or food-for-work modality, enabling HHs to purchase food from local markets wherever possible. Partners will include market assessments to determine the feasible modality to adopt for the project to adjust to any potential economic volatility. Besides direct food assistance, rehabilitation of productive assets through vouchers/food for work (specifically to combat the locust infestation and/or improve agricultural land), provision of tools for agricultural rehabilitations, small livestock and distribution of goats, vegetable seeds and organic fertilizer will be part of the approach to rebuild livelihoods. Communities will be trained/sensitized on preparation and response to combating the locust infestation, as well as food handling, preparation and preservation, vegetable production, climate smart agriculture, small livestock management and post-harvest management training. Training and provision of tools and inputs for garden/kitchen farming will have an impact on the longer-term food security of the communities, reinforcing their capacities and resilience in areas that are already combating recurring drought. Cash Both conditional and unconditional modalities will be used in this intervention, depending on needs, household ability and local circumstances. The most vulnerable HHs will be targeted for the receipt of unconditional MPC, including PLW, female-headed households, child-headed households, elders without caregivers, orphans, people with disabilities and other with known and identified vulnerabilities. Cash for work (CFW) activities will target for 5 manual labour and will target only the transitory food insecure pastoral/agro pastoral/farmer households severely affected by desert locust. CFW benefits both recipients of cash as well as the wider community through the rehabilitation of community assets. CFW activities include ground control interventions and distribution of CfW tools. Specific COVID guidelines from the clusters will be followed. As a safety measure, cash is transferred mostly via digital/mobile means, to ensure that no money is handled. WASH WASH activities will focus on awareness raising around hygiene promotion, the installation of handwashing stations, distribution of hygiene kits/PPE and disinfection of public spaces. In some areas, partners will repair and rehabilitate wells, construct water springs, and install water storage barrels. COVID-19 handwashing facilities will also be installed at public gathering places including markets and IDP centers and health/nutrition centers In some areas, the installation/preparation of bore holes will also be supported. Hygiene promotion: Public information campaigns in the project areas on how to protect yourself and others from the COVID-19 virus to prevent the spread of COVID, to reach the most affected households. Several information and education materials will be developed (leaflets, posters etc.) , printed and distributed to target households in local language to address key measures of COVID-19 virus prevention education. In Somalia, a call center for questions on COVID-19 has been established together by Oxfam and the Ministry of Health, this will be promoted across all partners in Somalia. Health Save the Children will train health care workers on COVID-19 drug guidelines and MHPSS. The health workers will be provided with Personal Protective Equipment (PPE).

title.narrative: PanameriCaña

description.narrative: Through PanAmericaña (PanAm) we promote best industrial and agricultural practices in sugarcane production. In 2020, we expanded our scope to 38 mills supported in Mexico, Honduras, Dominican Republic, El Salvador and Haiti to make the necessary investments and adjustments in sustainable sugarcane production, using Bonsucro as a benchmark. Through these mills we have reached 14,487 sugarcane producers and 28,532 workers, bringing 261,049 hectares under better management practices. The Covid-19 pandemic made us adjust to the new context, changing our communication channels with the producers, but it also brought opportunities in terms of visibility and scope of this initiative. Together with sugar mill San Antonio we have organized a virtual event to discuss occupational health and safety in sugarcane production with more than 100 participants from all over the continent. We also organized a conference to discuss the advantages and disadvantages of mechanized harvest, which was later replicated with the Mexican CNPR (National Association of Sugarcane Growers), bringing the discussion to the sugarcane producers. Our strategy in Mexico shows clear signs of a successful business case based on connecting sustainability issues with increase in productivity and cost reduction. We are exploring the best way to scale this up with resources from the sector. For the other countries in Central America and the Carribean we find difficulties to gain traction as productivity and efficiency in general are higher and require a more compliance based strategy. Compliance backed strategies are complex as they need a higher level of trust (more difficult to build during Covid-19 times) and the international market pull for sustainably produced sugarcane is currently not encouraging enough for the producers.

Better Mill Initiative (BMI) Ethiopia

description.narrative: In Ethiopia, the Better Mill Initiative mainly focused on online/remote activities. These included updating partners on the activities as well as creating awareness on Covid-19 by delivering brochures and masks to our staff, beneficiaries and partners. The Better Mill Initiative project trained on health and safety in the 24 factories focusing on health issues, especially awareness creation and prevention mechanisms. The project also carried out leadership training for the Ethiopian Management Institute for management staff of three factories. A training on soft skills targeting 30 women workers was also carried out. In addition, we conducted gender related grievance handling mechanisms for 22 women labour unions leaders from four textile and garment factories. Through our training to workers and factory management, we worked to improve the working conditions for 25,400 workers. The economic and environmental performance improvements are limited due to the effect of the global pandemic. This also counts for trading activities between factories and markets in Europe and the USA. Revival of these markets including other business channels will gradually improve as global travel restrictions during the pandemic ease. There are different organizations working in the same sector, such as, FNV, ILO, GIZ, IDH and SIWI. Most of the organizations have good communication with us and try to minimize duplication effort in the factories. The Dutch Embassy is one of the steering committee members of the project and we update them once every six months.

Promoting sustainable cotton & garment value chain from Ethiopian cotton to European consumers

description.narrative: Bottom UP! Initiative (promoting a sustainable cotton & garment value chain from Ethiopian cotton to European consumers), match funded by the EU. This project promotes the adoption of responsible social & environmental practices by 14 cotton and garment factories and 2,000 cotton farmers along the value chain. The programme is partially implemented in Tigray, the region that was under a state of emergency in 2020. Despite the Covid-19 pandemic, the floodings and the state of Emergency in Tigray, we were able to train 118 workers in ginneries on occupational health and safety (OHS) and cleaner production. 2.8 tonnes of improved cotton seeds were supplied to 554 cotton farmers (400 ha) and 832 cotton farmers (of which 125 were women) have been supported on integrated pest management and have access to improved seeds and crop protection inputs and their markets. We worked closely with Ethiopian Textile Industry, Development Institute (ETIDI), Ethiopian Textile and Garment Manufacturers Association (ETGAMA), and Ethiopian Cotton Producers Exporters and Ginners Association (ECPGEA), to train 728 workers to adopt Good Practices on safe working conditions. The global pandemic, the political instability (i.e. the Tigray conflict) but also the flooding in the Afar region, which affected the cotton farms, delayed the implementation and momentum of planned activities. tanneries have participated in cleaner leather production workshops. We have partnered with LIDI, Ethiopian Leather Industries Association (ELIA), UNIDO and GIZ to influence policy making in the leather sector in general. We partnered with LIDI to scale-up the adaptation of cleaner leather production, especially in chrome-free/less chrome leather for shoe upper upholstery. We organised a marketing visit for European buyers to 10 tanneries and leather product manufacturers. 10 tanneries and manufacturers were supported to participate in the 11th All African Leather Fair in Ethiopia.

# of local platforms, networks, producer groups established and strengthened
Improving Production&Market Capacity of Smallholder Fruit&Vegetable Farmers in Southern Africa

description.narrative: In Mozambique, South Africa, and Zambia, training in local-gap and global-gap has improved the food safety of horticulture in the project. 2,207 farmers are now meeting the agreed standard producing horticulture on 5,550 hectares. With good practices improving, access to capital and a more stable connection with the market become the major challenges. Slowly, market linkages are being developed but farmers continue to struggle to meet the market quantity, quality and food-safety requirements. Pilots with the “fresh-hubs“, downstream pack-houses for cold chain logistics, are promising but need time outside the Covid-19 reality to prove effective when conditions normalize. The pandemic caused a considerable reduction in logistics and therefore income and the capacity to contract loans. In 2020, we successfully supported 559 farmers to obtain new loans, a reduction of 42% compared to the year before. The programme is closely linked to the intensive policy dialogue on setting regulatory frameworks for sustainable and safe fruit and vegetables in the region, covered under our Advocacy for Change programme. The training and following practice has materialized the Mozbopa standard as the national reference for the sector in Mozambique. A nice example of how Practice and Advocacy projects can become complementary and reinforce processes.

title.narrative: Grazing Lands, Livestock and Climate Resilient Mitigation in the Kafue Basin

description.narrative: In Zambia the different components of our livestock project are coming together with a more solid involvement from the local leadership. An excursion spurred the adoption of holistic grassland management, following the concept of high density planned rotation on 60,700 hectares. 300 cattle farmers were additionally trained in good practices of controlled burning, intercropping and manure compositing. The use of our cattle grading mobile application is becoming functional, providing both a tool for making better business deals and serving as an awareness building tool for cattle farmers. The combination of 23 village saving and loan associations (VSLA’s) used by 435 famers, with training of 61 youth on entrepreneurship and improved leather treatment in 4 village factories with 52 trainees, provides a powerful emerging combination of downstream value creation for the rural communities. The impact is clear with improved yields for maize (35%) and better calving rates (85%) leading to a higher income (103,000 euros collectively) and increased participation of youth and women (nearing 50%). A business model is emerging and even with Covid-19, the targets were surpassed in 2020, while ramping up the services and numbers of beneficiaries will be the major challenge for 2021.

title.narrative: Southern Africa Towards Soy Bean Import Substitution

description.narrative: In Mozambique, Malawi and Zambia a series of services for the soy sector starts to reinforce each other and a business model is emerging. Seed multiplication is taken up by selected farmers and provides improved income. Better seed and income permit better investment into the soy crop and for this, good practices training, and soil analysis services are provided. A better projected yield enables the provision of financial services, but for this, improved financial literacy of the farming household is also required, consequently financial literacy training was included in the training curriculum. Using the increased yield has stimulated some farmers to explore downstream businesses like chicken raising. In different stages of this development effort, farmers and groups are engaged. Covid-19 hampered most of the good practices training, ending up with 25% fewer producers supported than we expected (38,402 instead of the 51,000 planned). Still, 19,169 farmers reported to have improved their income as a result of the improved agri services. 149,000 hectares in total were brought under better management practices, and close to 35,000 farmers are organized into 50 soy farmer groups, of which 13 are led by women. A mix of individual entrepreneurs, local cooperatives and small companies totalling 249 service providers, were engaged in the project with soil analysis, extension service, input delivery, etc. The use of digital tools among both farmers and service providers is increasing and a system is considered that integrates these services into a single platform.

Proven good practices in agriculture, mining & industry available
# of tools and models that facilitate the implementation of GP developed and tes
Sugarcane Programme for Southern Africa

description.narrative: The sugarcane sector in Southern Africa is dominated by three large companies: lllovo, Tongaat Hullett and TSB; smallholders are contract farmers with limited, if any, negotiation power. In 2020, the sugarcane sector in Southern Africa was hampered by Covid-19, causing delays in the field work and in the negotiations in Zambia for possible continuation. Digital training materials were developed and WhatsApp groups were established to continue providing training and support to 4,675 farmers. The implementation of good production practices led to yields increase in Malawi (25%) and in South Africa (2%). In Zambia, although farmers experienced an improvement in 2019 of 17%, their productivity in 2020 was affected by severe droughts, which caused a yield drop (-20%). Therefore, we have initiated negotiations with Illovo and CRIDF, to start a revolving fund for small growers in Zambia, that allows them to convert their irrigation systems into water efficient systems such as drip irrigation. We have collaborated with Illovo in South Africa to deliver training to the growers and their contractors on business management and labour relations. This has led to the improvement of the relations between 2,133 growers and their contractors, holding them accountable for the service they are providing. Sugarcane farmers in Malawi, managed to raise funds (68,000 euros) to maintain their association, to influence the policy framework with the government. They have also negotiated a 7,5% sucrose price increase (from USD318 to USD342) with sugar giant Illovo. In Zambia, we assisted the sugarcane farmers to finalize the establishment of the Sugarcane Association of Zambia, where growers and millers agree on the legislation needed for the sector, and through which they advocate for the improvements in the regulatory frameworks.

We successfully managed to restore the working relationship between KCGL and the bank and set up a partnership model for the association. KCGL was assisted to revise their cashflow projections and present new projections to the bank and to negotiate for better conditions to their loan repayment.

title.narrative: Model for collaborative and cost-effective farmer assistance

description.narrative: In Brazil, we work together with companies, farmer cooperatives and associations to implement digital technical assistance tools, to fine tune and strengthen their service provision models, and to (re)train their extension workers. Our digital tools allow farmer associations and cooperatives to reshape their services to fit better the farmers’ needs, and to make their Technical Assistance (TA) more effective. Extension workers have access to custom work plans based on farmer assessments, and so provide tailored support to the farmers. In 2020 we have been working with 19 sugarcane farmer associations and 1 cocoa farmer organization reaching 6,658 farmers. We have also supported 263 citrus producers through digital channels. Together with our partner Raízen, the biggest sugarcane milling group in the world, we reached 26 mills and their 2,152 sugarcane suppliers. Through these interventions we brought 478,377 hectares under sustainable management practices. From 2021 onwards, Raízen will continue implementing the Technical Assistance model and Solidaridad tools and data-advisory support at own cost. The work with the sugarcane farmer associations in 2020, was partly hampered by Covid-19 restrictions, reducing the outreach by 10%. However, the collected data through different digital tools gave the associations a much better insight in farmers’ needs and priorities, and helped the associations to re-shape the services to its members. In collaboration with SENAR (National Rural Learning Service), we continued gathering data from coffee farmers to develop a strategy to incorporate a Climate-smart Agriculture (CSA) component to the portfolio of rural advisory services in Minas Gerais. In cocoa, we started to develop the business case for the Technical Assistance service provision, which is being tested by Coopercau (farmers cooperative). We also supported Cargill and Olam to develop sustainability criteria to implement their barter scheme, which has the potential to become a rewarding mechanism for smallholder farmers that apply zero-deforestation practices. This would bring sustainability to the core of the value chain by embedding a reward mechanism that represents more productivity and income to the producers. Together with Cutrale, one of the main orange juice processing industries in the world, and its main buyers, Coca-Cola, Eckes-Granini and Innocent Drinks, we are reaching producers through online training, local partners and remote assistance. This initiative was in its first stages and it was heavily affected by the Covid-19 pandemic because field visits are key for the trust-building process, and we could reach most of them only through digital media. We expect to make up for this in 2021, provided that the Covid-19 situation in Brazil improves.

comment.narrative: Considering the crises of the orange sector, Solidaridad was not able to develop an assistance program for famers. However, the year of 2018 was a strategic year for the orange project. We built new strategies to approach new partners. We participated on a task force that visited producers and sectorial organizations, like Fundecitrus, together with international industry members, like Coca-cola, Innocent, and other chain members, like Cutrale. Also, we were accepted as a member on the Brazilian Citrus Chamber on the Ministry of Agriculture. We are current building a proposal for a pre-competitive sectorial project, engaging 600 orange partners, to be presented on the chamber���������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������s next meeting on 12th March 2019. comment.narrative: Sugarcane ELO: 906 - 861 cumulative from 2018 Method: sum of of producers who have given the expected answer for 80% or more for the set of questions the compose the indicator (list of questions available under request.) From Jan/19 to March/19 the data was collected through RHES, while from April to December, through ES. The number is the sum of both results. Obs1: if the farmer was assessed in both platform, only ES result is accounted; Obs2: we consider the farmers the have answered 80% or more of questions that compose the indicator. Obs3: Not applicable = compliance. Sugarcane MC: 0 Results explanation: the farmers adherence to the Farming Solution app was less than expected what negatively affected the KPI. Also, the use of Extension Solution app started in the last quarter of 2019. So, the extensionists just visited the farmers once to make the diagnosis. The follow-up visits to understand the implemented practices will start in 2020.

title.narrative: # of producers and miners (M/F/youth) that implement Good Practices

comment.narrative: The original goal of 200 for 2020 refers to the second year of the partnership with Cutrale and Coca Cola. However, due to delays, the partnership will be actually in year 1 of implementation in 2020. The original goal for Year 1 was 60 producers. We reduced this 60 figure to 10 farmers to take into account the impacts of Covid-19 on the project. We have not started to use the ES tool in 2020 because of the pandemic. This number will increase only after the trainings have been done, which are delayed as well.

title.narrative: Private and public sector decision-makers agree to develop measures
Endorsed agenda and work plan or action plan available
Responsible practices in the ASM Peruvian and Colombian gold sectors

description.narrative:
In Peru and Colombia, we want to integrate and formalize Artisanal and Small-scale Miners (ASM), into the formal gold value chain by working with Large Scale Mines (LSM). In 2020 we have developed new partnerships with 2 large scale and industrial mining companies with 450 artisanal miners operating within their concessions. The Covid-19 crisis limited our ability to work with all mines we had foreseen for 2020. One LSM partner needed to prioritize controlling the Covid-19 infections within its own operations in order to avoid shutdown, and we could re-engage only in December. The start-up activities with a third LSM partner were delayed because of the restrictions and we can start with the first visits only in July. Yet we were able to work with one LSM, integrating 90 artisanal miners from 8 ASM groups into its concession. The benefits of this model are starting to show: material and input costs for small scale miners reduced by 25%, ore transportation time reduced by 30% and the use of mercury reduced with 36.8kgs in 2020. We made a start with the development of the first financial product specifically for ASM in Peru.
Red Social joined us to develop an initiative to study and alleviate Covid-19 effects among Pallaqueras (women miners): the Pallaqueras’ assistance platform (read more here). Through this platform we raised funds (over US$11,000) and distributed food supplies to 560 families in Arequipa, Puno and Ayacucho (Peru). We offered a remote capacity building program to adjust their work practices, daily social activities and family routines to the Covid-19 scenario. And we set up a call center that provides timely information on how to prevent and handle Covid-19 infections. In Colombia, the Covid-19 restrictions also delayed the process of building new partnerships, but from September onwards we could finalize new partnerships to provide technical and formalization assistance for 35 artisanal miners, organized in 7 ASM groups.
Together with local and international CSO partners and public authorities we developed safety protocols and booklets for the ASM sector to cope with the Covid-19 crisis (“MAPE sin Covid-19” -ASM without Covid-19- in Peru and Colombia).

comment.narrative: Asociaci������������������������������������������������������n de Mineros Artesanales Pepas de Oro de Pampamarca (AMAPOP) has dramatically increased their production from 3kg gold / month (working with 80 miners), pre Solidaridad?s intervention to up to 20 kg gold / month (working with 260 miners), post Solidaridad?s intervention doubling their per capita production. However, it is important to note that this increase is also due to the fact that the ASMO found a very generous gold vein in their operations. Nonetheless, due to their strengthened organisational capacities, they?ve been able to better organise themselves and to increase their labour production under safer practices.

DRA ZZJR 2020 - ZCC

description.narrative: As part of the Dutch Relief Alliance ‘s (DRA) Zambia/ Zimbabwe Joint Response ( ZZJR) ICCO is working in Zimbabwe to address the drought crisis in the bordering region of Zambia and Zimbabwe. These regions have suffered not only from drought but also from flash floods that occurred in early 2020. Many rural community water points have dried out and cannot meet the needs of the communities and an increasing number of people are using unsafe water resources. The food security situation is growing ever more precarious, as millions of Zimbabweans require food assistance, health, and nutrition support. In collaboration with its local partner, Zimbabwe Council of Churches (ZCC), ICCO is addressing nutrition, food, livelihood assistance in the Marondera and Seke districts within Mashonaland East. Interventions aim to address immediate needs and prepare communities for similar climate change-related events. Through a number of interventions, from distributing food parcels to restoring water points, addressing malnutrition in children and pregnant and breastfeeding mothers, distribution of small livestock and garden inputs to workshops on climate-smart agriculture practices, ICCO is linking emergency relief with rehabilitation and economic recovery to restore depleted livelihoods recovery of vulnerable rural communities. As the COVID-19 pandemic is spreading through the world, ICCO is linking rapid emergency relief with COVID-19 humanitarian response in its drought response program to promote infection prevention and awareness-raising among vulnerable rural communities. Our COVID-19 approach is focusing on decreasing the spread of the virus by implementing WASH interventions such as the distribution of hygiene kits and community sensitization and awareness-raising on COVID-19.

Due to droughts and flooding, millions of people are severely affected by food insecurity and access to clean water. In Zimbabwe, ICCO is responding to urgent humanitarian needs and together with Zimbabwe Council of Churches and other partners in DRA ( Dutch Relief Alliance) provides livelihood support, distribution of food vouchers, small livestock & garden inputs and nutrition support for children and pregnant women, together with COVID-19 prevention and awareness-raising activities.
